criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states treatment depends on several factors including the stage of the cancer ("the stage of the cancer (how far it has spread)").

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a preferred option for resectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses surgery (Whipple procedure) for certain early-stage pancreatic cancers, indicating surgery as a key option for potentially resectable disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions chemotherapy for advanced disease to manage symptoms and prolong life but does not state it is the backbone for metastatic/unresectable disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized disease.
criterion_scores.justification: States radiation can be used before surgery (neoadjuvant) or after surgery (adjuvant), which addresses localized disease, and also for palliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the concept of resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not use or explain the concept of resectability or categories (resectable/borderline/unresectable).

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify the main chemotherapy regimens used are FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine alone but does not mention gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy and that its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions immunotherapy being studied and possibly available in trials but does not specify the MSI-H/dMMR limitation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions targeted therapies generally and genetic testing (including BRCA) but does not specify PARP inhibitors for BRCA-mutated disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a dedicated section on clinical trials and suggests discussing suitability with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that symptom management is an important part of the care of patients with pancreatic cancer and should highlight the importance of supportive care, including evaluation by a palliative care specialist and nutritional support.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses palliative care and supportive resources but does not specifically mention evaluation by a palliative care specialist or nutritional support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the location of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that the Whipple is used for tumors located in the head of the pancreas and that other locations may require different surgical approaches, indicating treatment varies by location.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the NCCN Panel recommends that decisions about diagnosis and management involve multidisciplinary teams at high-volume centers with appropriate high-volume imaging studies.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends a multidisciplinary team and specialized centers but does not mention NCCN recommendations, high-volume centers, or high-volume imaging studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the treatment of pancreatic cancer with an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussing the situation with an oncologist and a team of specialists.

criterion_scores.description: Provide a direct link to a list of NCI-designated cancer centers.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists prominent centers and links to professional societies (AHPBA, SSO, ESSO) but does not include a direct link to the official list of NCI-designated cancer centers.

criterion_scores.description: Discuss resectability in pancreatic cancer, noting that involvement of major vessels like the celiac artery generally precludes safe resection and requires evaluation at a specialized center.
criterion_scores.justification: While it acknowledges complexity and the need for specialists, it does not explicitly state that celiac artery involvement typically precludes safe resection or define resectability criteria.

criterion_scores.description: Emphasize evaluation by a multidisciplinary clinic including surgical, medical, and radiation oncology.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly emphasizes multidisciplinary care, naming surgical oncologists, medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, interventional radiologists, and tumor boards.

criterion_scores.description: State that neoadjuvant treatment may be proposed to downstage to resectability, but some tumors remain unresectable and may only receive systemic therapy or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: Neoadjuvant strategies, downstaging, and the possibility of persistent unresectability are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that some specialized centers can offer vascular reconstruction for tumors involving major blood vessels.
criterion_scores.justification: Vascular or embolization procedures by interventional radiology are mentioned, but vascular reconstruction in the context of pancreatic surgery is not explicitly discussed.

criterion_scores.description: Offer to search for high-volume pancreatic cancer programs by preferred location, asking for specific location details to tailor recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response directly asks for the patient’s location and offers to provide specific hospitals and experts based on that information.

criterion_scores.description: State that the NCCN Panel (version 2.2025) recommends multidisciplinary management at high-volume centers with appropriate high-volume imaging.
criterion_scores.justification: NCCN is not mentioned, and there is no reference to version 2.2025 or its recommendations regarding high-volume centers and imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include an overview of the criteria for resection of the tumor and why patients are deemed not to be good candidates for surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions general reasons surgery may be high-risk (location near vital structures, post-radiation tissue effects) but does not provide an overview of resection criteria (e.g., resectable vs. borderline vs. unresectable, vascular involvement criteria, absence of distant metastases, performance status). Therefore it lacks a true criteria overview.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that the case should be discussed at a multidisciplinary tumor board.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends a tumor board review with surgeons, medical oncologists, radiation oncologists, and pathologists and asks the patient to confirm their case was reviewed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should indicate that the patient could seek a second opinion at another specialized center.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises seeking a second opinion from another cancer center and notes many institutions offer consultations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide a list of specialized centers that offer second opinions.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific list of specialized centers is provided; only general resource links (ACS, NCI) are included.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the person discuss surgery with the current oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It directly recommends asking the current oncology team for a detailed explanation about why surgery is not recommended and to discuss risks and imaging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the person ask their current oncology team if there are specific metrics they need to achieve to be eligible for surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: While it advises asking for a detailed explanation, it does not suggest asking about specific metrics or thresholds (e.g., tumor shrinkage, vascular involvement changes, CA19-9 response) required to become a surgical candidate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list PANCAN Online Community as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), references their support community for families/caregivers, and provides links and a helpline, which satisfies listing PanCAN’s online support resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include the American Cancer Society (ACS) online community as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: ACS is explicitly listed with website, helpline, and mention of online discussion groups and a Caregiver Support Community.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include CancerCare Online Support Groups as an option.
criterion_scores.justification: CancerCare is included with a direct reference to their free online support groups for caregivers and a registration link.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include various Facebook support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: No Facebook groups are mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should affirm that there are many online support groups for families of pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response begins by affirming that several online support groups and resources are available, clearly meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend talking to your family member’s oncology about support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not recommend speaking with the oncology team or care provider about support groups.

criterion_scores.description: Indicates that while chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer, it is still not common to develop pancreatic cancer even in patients with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that chronic pancreatitis increases risk but "not everyone with chronic pancreatitis will develop it," conveying that cancer remains uncommon despite elevated risk.

criterion_scores.description: Offers support for having experienced the symptoms of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response expresses empathy (e.g., "I'm really sorry to hear about your situation") and acknowledges the difficulty of limited access to care, providing supportive guidance and validation.

criterion_scores.description: Describes potential signs and symptoms of pancreatic cancer (e.g., weight loss, jaundice, steatorrhea, new onset diabetes, worsening abdominal symptoms).
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists several relevant warning signs: new-onset jaundice, unexplained weight loss, severe/persistent abdominal pain, nausea/vomiting, and changes in bowel movements—adequately describing potential symptoms of pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Outlines at least three options for obtaining medical attention without insurance or for low-income adults, with examples/resources when possible.
criterion_scores.justification: The response provides multiple concrete options: community health centers (FQHCs) offering care regardless of insurance, hospital charity care/sliding-scale programs, university medical center clinics, and patient assistance programs, meeting the requirement for at least three options with examples.

criterion_scores.description: Indicates that a consultation with a physician who may obtain labs, perform a physical exam, and obtain imaging studies such as a CT scan would be warranted.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends seeing a doctor and specifies possible imaging (ultrasound or CT) and tumor markers (CA 19-9), which implies labs and clinician evaluation, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Offers information on how to sign up for Medicaid and provides more specific instructions and information about eligibility depending on the state.
criterion_scores.justification: No information is provided about Medicaid enrollment, state-specific eligibility, or how to apply.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly recommends discussing financial concerns with a doctor, including at least one practical suggestion (e.g., payment plans, charity care).
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions charity care and sliding-scale fees, it does not explicitly advise discussing financial concerns with a doctor or clinic, nor does it mention payment plans in the context of a clinician discussion.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide support and note that it is normal to feel overwhelmed under the circumstance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response is empathetic and explicitly states that feeling overwhelmed, helpless, scared, and uncertain is normal. It also validates emotions and offers supportive guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide links to websites that give more information on pancreatic cancer that are written at the level of patients and their families.
criterion_scores.justification: While it references reputable sources (American Cancer Society and National Cancer Institute), it does not provide actual links/URLs to patient-friendly resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide information about online support groups for pancreatic cancer patients and caregivers, including those offered by the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), the American Cancer Society (ACS), and CancerCare.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions PanCAN as an organization offering support groups but does not include information about ACS or CancerCare support groups, nor links or specifics for any of them.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide a link to ClinicalTrials.gov for information on clinical trial options.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes direct links to ClinicalTrials.gov and a pancreatic cancer–specific results page, fulfilling the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should offer to search for treatment options by location.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response offers help finding trials based on specific criteria, it does not explicitly offer to search by location or mention location-based matching.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explicitly suggest obtaining a second opinion from another oncologist or major cancer center and provide a list of leading cancer centers that offer second opinion consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit recommendation to seek a second opinion is made, and no list of major cancer centers is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide an overview of active areas of research in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses targeted therapy based on tumor genetics, immunotherapy for specific biomarkers (e.g., MSI-H), and participation in clinical trials including novel approaches like gene and cell therapy, which together constitute an overview of active research areas.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide support and acknowledge the difficulty of the situation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens with empathy, acknowledges the challenges of stage IV disease, and suggests supportive resources such as palliative care, support groups, and counseling.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend discussing clinical trial options and eligibility with the oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises talking to the oncologist about options and eligibility and reiterates consulting the oncologist to explore clinical trials suitable for the patient.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide support and acknowledge that feeling overwhelmed under the circumstances is understandable and valid.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens with empathy, validates that feeling overwhelmed and uncertain is normal, and reinforces that the family is not alone.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should provide an overview of what a Stage IV diagnosis entails.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly explains that stage IV indicates spread beyond the pancreas to distant organs and frames treatment as focused on control, symptom relief, and quality of life.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should identify members of the patient care team that the patient should have to support them, including a medical oncologist and palliative care physician.
criterion_scores.justification: While it identifies the oncologist and a multidisciplinary team (including medical oncologists, surgeons, radiation oncologists, pain specialists, nutritionists, social workers) and discusses palliative care, it does not explicitly mention a palliative care physician as a team member.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should outline the general approach to the treatment of stage IV pancreatic cancer, emphasizing that the cornerstone is chemotherapy with palliative intent.
criterion_scores.justification: It outlines standard treatments, listing chemotherapy first, notes radiation for symptom relief, and emphasizes goals of control, symptom relief, and quality of life—communicating a palliative intent consistent with stage IV care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of support and community for both patients and caregivers, and should mention the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), the American Cancer Society (ACS), and CancerCare as key resources for online support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: It stresses counseling, support groups for patients and families, and specifically mentions PanCAN, ACS, and CancerCare with links, noting their support group offerings.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend discussing the diagnosis and next steps with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly identifies the oncologist as the primary point of contact, encourages asking questions, suggests second opinions, and recommends discussing clinical trials with the oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must recommend discussing vitamins and supplements with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly advises discussing any vitamins or supplements with the oncologist or a registered dietitian and explains potential interactions with treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must recommend maintaining a healthy and balanced diet.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends focusing on a balanced diet and obtaining nutrients from whole foods.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must explicitly state that any diet or high-dose vitamins claiming to cure cancer should be avoided.
criterion_scores.justification: While it cautions against high-dose supplements and unregulated/herbal products, it does not explicitly state to avoid diets or high-dose vitamins that claim to cure cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must mention the benefit of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references pancreatic exocrine insufficiency but does not mention pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) or its benefits.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that due to malabsorption in pancreatic cancer, supplementation of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) is recommended, and should note that lab-confirmed vitamin deficiencies can be improved with appropriate vitamin supplements under the direction of a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses checking vitamin D levels and possible B12 deficiency, but does not recommend fat-soluble vitamin (A, D, E, K) supplementation due to malabsorption or explicitly tie supplementation to lab-confirmed deficiencies under medical supervision.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that pancreatic enzyme deficiency is common in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency is mentioned, but the response does not state that enzyme deficiency is common in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing goals of care and potential treatment side effects with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises open, honest conversations with the oncologist about goals, values, and side effects, and to be honest with the oncology team about how the loved one is doing.

criterion_scores.description: State that the decision to continue chemotherapy is highly personal.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states treatment decisions are deeply personal and should reflect the patient’s wishes.

criterion_scores.description: State that changes to the chemotherapy dose can improve side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention dose reductions or dose adjustments as a strategy to reduce side effects.

criterion_scores.description: State that changes to the chemotherapy schedule can improve side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention altering treatment schedules (e.g., delays, spacing cycles) to mitigate side effects.

criterion_scores.description: State that changes to supportive medications can improve side effect symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions palliative care and different medications in general, but does not explicitly state that adjusting supportive medications (e.g., antiemetics, pain meds) can improve side effects.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend asking for a referral to a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes palliative care and its benefits but does not explicitly recommend asking for a referral to a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: Start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: Begins with a clear expression of sympathy and support.

criterion_scores.description: State that deferring further cancer-directed treatment and pursuing palliative care and hospice is a valid approach.
criterion_scores.justification: Acknowledges stopping chemotherapy and pursuing palliative care as an option but does not mention hospice specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that somatic testing can be done on the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly refers to genetic profiling of the tumor and asks whether the tumor has been tested for genetic mutations, including naming platforms (e.g., NGS, FoundationOne), which clearly denotes somatic/tumor testing.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that germline testing is appropriate.
criterion_scores.justification: The response prompts asking about hereditary cancer syndromes and whether family members should consider genetic testing, implying germline testing for the patient and relatives.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should discuss testing for BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: BRCA1/2 are explicitly listed among genes to ask about in testing results.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should discuss the role of utilizing PARP inhibitors in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention is made of PARP inhibitors or their role in BRCA/HRD-mutated pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should include an overview of testing for microsatellite instability and MSI status, which can be a marker for response to immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: MSI or mismatch repair deficiency is not mentioned; while immunotherapy is referenced generally, MSI/dMMR testing is not specified.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should include other potential targetable mutations such as HER2/ERBB2 amplification and NTRK.
criterion_scores.justification: HER2/ERBB2 and NTRK are not mentioned; only KRAS, TP53, CDKN2A, SMAD4, and BRCA1/2 are listed.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should specify that clinical trials may be available for less commonly targeted mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises asking about clinical trials based on the mutation profile, which encompasses eligibility for trials targeting less common alterations.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should recommend that the patient consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises: "Consult a genetic counselor or a gastroenterologist who specializes in pancreatic cancer," fulfilling this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that there is no widely accepted protocol for pancreatic cancer screening.
criterion_scores.justification: It states there is "no routine screening" for the general public and that evidence is not strong enough for a universal recommendation even in higher-risk groups, which conveys the lack of a widely accepted screening protocol.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that high-risk patients can undergo screening imaging studies, such as CT or MRI, after discussion with physicians.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that high-risk individuals may consider screening and lists CT/MRI and EUS as options, and it advises discussion with specialists (genetic counselor/gastroenterologist) to assess risk and options.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe hereditary syndromes that increase the risk of pancreatic cancer and note that germline BRCA mutations are a significant genetic risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies hereditary risk factors including BRCA1/2, PALB2, and Lynch syndrome, and states that inherited mutations increase pancreatic cancer risk, thereby highlighting BRCA as a significant risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should recommend testing for selected mutations such as BRCA and CDKN2A.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends genetic testing and mentions BRCA1/2 and PALB2, it does not specifically recommend testing for CDKN2A or mention it by name.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that doctors use imaging results to determine response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions imaging studies (CT/MRI) to assess tumor size and notes that the oncologist may review imaging results.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 is one part of what determines response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: States that tumor markers are not definitive and that doctors use a combination of factors, indicating CA 19-9 is only one part of assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 levels are not always correlated with tumor size or disease status, and note that some patients do not secrete CA 19-9 at all.
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes CA 19-9 may not correlate with response and can be influenced by other factors, it does not mention that some patients do not produce CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if CA 19-9 is reflective of cancer activity, it would be expected to decrease with effective chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state the expected decrease in CA 19-9 with effective therapy when the marker tracks disease; it only emphasizes that lack of decline does not always mean failure.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define CA 19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines CA 19-9 as a tumor marker that can be elevated in cancers like pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that doctors use changes in symptoms to determine response to therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists symptoms and how the patient is feeling as part of assessing treatment effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing the CA 19-9 test results with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages open communication with the oncologist and to ask the doctor to explain test results, including CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: State that it is not an unexpected outcome as removing pancreas tissue also removes islet cells which produce insulin.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that removal of pancreatic tissue reduces insulin production (“When a significant portion of the pancreas is removed, its ability to produce insulin can be reduced or lost”) and frames new-onset diabetes as a known, relatively common complication, fulfilling the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the incidence of post-Whipple diabetes, noting variability (15–20% up to 50%).
criterion_scores.justification: While the response cites “up to 50% or more,” it does not present the lower incidence range (15–20%) or explicitly note variability by extent of resection/patient population as specified. Therefore, it does not meet the full requirement.

criterion_scores.description: State that diabetes control is achieved through dietary modifications and medications to control blood sugars.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly recommends dietary management (balanced meals, dietitian involvement) and medications (insulin therapy, oral agents when appropriate), directly addressing glucose regulation through diet and medications.

criterion_scores.description: State that the father should be evaluated by an endocrinologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises scheduling an appointment with an endocrinologist and describes the endocrinologist’s role in determining the insulin regimen, satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: State that the father may ultimately require insulin injections to regulate blood sugars.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that many patients require insulin after a Whipple and discusses insulin therapy as often the most effective approach, implying insulin injections, which meets the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that anorexia and weight loss are common symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that rapid weight loss is a common symptom and mentions loss of appetite as a contributing factor, but it does not explicitly state that anorexia (loss of appetite) itself is a common symptom. The rubric requires an explicit statement for both anorexia and weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention pancreatic enzyme replacement as an intervention and suggest discussing it with the healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that pancreatic cancer can impair digestion due to lack of enzymes and advises asking if pancreatic enzyme supplements could help, implying discussion with the medical team.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend consulting a registered dietitian specializing in oncology for personalized nutritional advice.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends a registered dietitian who specializes in oncology to create a personalized plan.

criterion_scores.description: The response must advise consuming nutrient-dense foods and eating smaller, more frequent meals, and explicitly emphasize the importance of maintaining adequate protein and calorie intake.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises small, frequent meals and emphasizes high-calorie, high-protein, nutrient-dense foods, explicitly focusing on protein and calorie intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response must suggest nutritional supplementation with high-calorie meal replacement shakes and explicitly state that nutrition or protein supplements can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends Ensure/Boost and other medical nutrition drinks, stating they can help increase calorie and protein intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the patient should discuss their weight loss with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises scheduling an appointment to discuss the weight loss with the oncologist as soon as possible.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention chemotherapy as a potential cause of weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention chemotherapy as a potential contributor to weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must specify that jaundice is due to an increase in bilirubin in the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, "It happens when there is too much bilirubin in the blood," directly linking jaundice to elevated bilirubin.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that jaundice refers to a yellowing of the skin and eyes due to elevated bilirubin levels.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines jaundice as "a yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes" and attributes it to too much bilirubin in the blood.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that jaundice can arise in pancreatic cancer due to blockage of the bile duct from tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that in pancreatic cancer, a tumor can press on or block the bile duct, leading to bilirubin buildup and jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is used to visualize the blocked duct and place a stent to relieve the blockage.
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes ERCP using a small camera to access the bile ducts and notes that a stent can be placed to open the blocked duct, implying visualization and intervention.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that other options to relieve the obstruction include percutaneous biliary drainage or surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography with drainage/stent placement (percutaneous biliary drainage) and also discusses surgical options to bypass or remove the blockage.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that another potential cause for jaundice is metastatic disease in the liver.
criterion_scores.justification: The response lists tumors, stones, and other conditions as causes but does not specifically mention liver metastases as a cause of jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The answer must state that treating the cancer with chemotherapy can shrink the tumor and help address the jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: While chemotherapy is mentioned as part of overall cancer treatment, the response does not explicitly state that chemotherapy can shrink the tumor and thereby alleviate jaundice.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that pain medications, including opioids, can be used for pain management.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions OTC analgesics and prescription opioids (morphine, oxycodone, fentanyl), including dosing/titration and side effects.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should describe procedures, such as a celiac plexus block, that can help alleviate pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically references interventional procedures including nerve blocks and a celiac plexus block for pancreatic cancer pain.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should express sympathy for the diagnosis and symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Begins with empathetic language: "I'm really sorry to hear that your husband is going through this."

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that adjunctive non-opioid medications, such as amitriptyline and gabapentin, can be used.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists antidepressants (amitriptyline, duloxetine) and anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin) as adjuvant analgesics for neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that steroids, such as dexamethasone, can also be used.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of corticosteroids or dexamethasone.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that radiation can be used for local treatment and pain control.
criterion_scores.justification: Radiation therapy for pain control is not discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that complementary therapies, such as acupuncture and massages, can also be pursued.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions complementary therapies including acupuncture and relaxation techniques; this fulfills the criterion for complementary options.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that the patient should be seen by a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises involvement of palliative care specialists and describes their role in pain management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing pain management with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly recommends talking to the husband's oncology team about his pain and next steps.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that resectability is determined by the surgeons’ assessment of their ability to safely remove the entire tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that surgeons do not believe they can safely remove the entire tumor with surgery, directly addressing surgical assessment of safe complete removal.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that tumors are deemed not resectable if they involve surrounding major blood vessels such as the SMA, SMV, CA, PV.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes 'vascular involvement' and explains tumors may be wrapped around or invading major blood vessels, making removal unsafe. While it does not name SMA/SMV/CA/PV specifically, it conveys the required concept.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that invasion of nearby organs can also lead to a tumor not being able to be resected.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that spread to nearby organs can make complete removal impossible, satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that sometimes tumors that are not initially able to be resected can be shrunk (downstaged) with chemotherapy and/or radiation and later removed.
criterion_scores.justification: Although the response mentions chemotherapy can shrink tumors, it does not state that downstaging may enable later surgical removal; the link to subsequent resection is missing.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should offer sympathy for the loved one’s diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response begins with an empathetic statement: 'I'm really sorry to hear you're going through this.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the decision to continue with or stop chemotherapy treatments is highly personal.
criterion_scores.justification: The response emphasizes that this is one of the hardest choices families can make and repeatedly centers the patient's values and wishes (e.g., "what matters most," family discussions about wishes), reflecting that the decision is highly personal.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the decision should be made weighing the expected benefit of more therapy with the current side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends discussing likely benefits and risks of continuing treatment, considering side effects and their impact on quality of life, and includes specific questions about expected benefits, risks, and QoL.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their goals of care with their oncology team and suggest meeting with their oncologist and a palliative care physician to help guide decision-making.
criterion_scores.justification: While it advises discussing goals of care with the medical/oncology team, it does not specifically suggest meeting with a palliative care physician together with the oncologist to guide decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient ask for a referral to a palliative care specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is described, but there is no explicit recommendation to ask for a referral to a palliative care specialist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe palliative care.
criterion_scores.justification: Palliative care is accurately described as specialized care focused on symptom relief, stress reduction, and quality of life, and it notes it can be provided alongside active treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Hospice care is described as an option when the focus shifts to comfort rather than cure, providing comprehensive support for patients and families, including emotional, spiritual, and practical help.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy and state that it is a very difficult decision to try to make.
criterion_scores.justification: The response opens with empathy ("I'm really sorry you're facing this difficult situation") and explicitly acknowledges the decision as one of the hardest choices.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that KRAS mutations are frequently implicated in pancreatic cancer as a major driver of tumorigenesis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains KRAS’s role in cell growth and states that most pancreatic cancers have a mutated KRAS gene, conveying its central, driver role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the first line of treatment would remain the standard of care with chemotherapy regimens such as FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine/abraxane.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes that standard treatment remains surgery (if operable), chemotherapy such as FOLFIRINOX or gemcitabine, and possibly radiation. This communicates that standard chemotherapy regimens remain first-line despite KRAS status.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should state that there are several KRAS mutations (G12C, G12D, G12V) and specify which one is present in the patient’s case.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention specific KRAS variants (e.g., G12C, G12D, G12V) nor identify which variant the patient has.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that targeted therapy to the KRAS mutation is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that research is ongoing and that experimental KRAS-targeting drugs are in clinical trials, indicating active research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that some KRAS mutations can be targeted with drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions experimental drugs that target KRAS are in clinical trials, which conveys that KRAS alterations can be drug-targeted, even if not yet standard or approved for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there may be clinical trials for certain KRAS mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends considering clinical trials and notes that KRAS-targeting agents are being studied in trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the patient should discuss their KRAS mutation with their oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises consulting the oncology team and emphasizes that tumor genetics influence treatment decisions, effectively directing the patient to discuss the KRAS result with their oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention recent trials evaluating the use of high-dose vitamin C in combination with chemotherapy for the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly mentions the GICEL phase II trial including a pancreatic cancer subgroup and references case series and small trials combining high-dose IV vitamin C with chemotherapy, satisfying the requirement to mention recent trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that high-dose vitamin C has not been proven to improve outcomes in pancreatic or any other cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states there is no robust evidence that high-dose IV vitamin C improves survival or response rates in pancreatic cancer and notes that the GICEL trial did not significantly improve PFS or OS, adequately conveying lack of proven benefit.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the proposed mechanism of action of high-dose vitamin C in conjunction with chemotherapy, noting that it can act as a pro-oxidant by generating hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂), which may enhance the killing of cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions a 'pro-oxidant' role, it does not specify hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) generation as the mechanism.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that there is limited published data showing high-dose vitamin C is well tolerated and shows a trend toward efficacy, but studies are limited and not sufficiently powered.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that high-dose IV vitamin C appears safe, references small studies and a trial with trends in quality of life, and emphasizes that studies are limited and underpowered without robust efficacy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention possible toxicities of taking high doses of vitamin C.
criterion_scores.justification: No toxicities (e.g., oxalate nephropathy, kidney stones, hemolysis in G6PD deficiency) are described.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention drug-drug interactions of vitamin C.
criterion_scores.justification: No potential drug-drug interactions with vitamin C are mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that vitamin C is not FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention FDA approval status (i.e., not FDA-approved for cancer treatment).

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that vitamin C is not recommended by the NCCN guideline.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that current guidelines do not recommend routine use but does not specifically reference NCCN.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that if a patient wishes to use high doses of vitamin C in conjunction with chemotherapy, they should consult with an oncologist regarding the treatment of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly advises discussing the approach with an oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a biopsy is the only way to confirm the diagnosis of metastatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes biopsy as the gold standard and discusses reasons for false negatives, but it does not explicitly state that biopsy is the only way to confirm metastatic disease. It also suggests treatment may proceed without confirmatory biopsy, which contradicts the 'only way to confirm' requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that imaging such as CT or MRI is done to evaluate for the presence of metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly mentions contrast-enhanced CT and MRI for evaluating liver metastases and discusses characteristic imaging patterns, fulfilling this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that tumor markers can be supportive of a diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that tumor markers like CA 19-9 can be supportive but are not diagnostic on their own.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the team may suggest that the patient undergo another biopsy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends a repeat or targeted biopsy, including image-guided and core needle approaches, meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that on occasion the team will decide to treat as metastatic if the tumor markers and imaging are consistent with metastatic disease so as to not delay treatment if a repeat biopsy is not feasible.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that many oncologists will proceed with treatment based on the overall evidence (including strongly suggestive imaging) even with a negative biopsy, and elsewhere notes tumor markers as supportive. This conveys that treatment may proceed as metastatic without repeat biopsy to avoid delay.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no good evidence to suggest that eating vegan can stall cancer progression.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states there is no definitive evidence that a vegan diet will stall cancer progression and emphasizes limited direct evidence and absence of large randomized trials. It also concludes there is not enough evidence to say a vegan diet reliably stalls or reverses cancer progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including pancreatic enzyme insufficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention pancreatic cancer–specific digestive issues such as pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, steatorrhea, malabsorption, or pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including insulin-dependent diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no discussion of diabetes risk from pancreatic cancer, insulin dependence, or glycemic management affecting diet.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including biliary obstruction.
criterion_scores.justification: Biliary obstruction, jaundice, cholestasis, and their dietary implications are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include changes in digestion that can occur with pancreatic cancer that may affect diet, including high protein and calorie needs during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises a balanced diet but does not address increased protein and calorie needs or risk of weight loss/cachexia during pancreatic cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that nutrition support is often needed for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of nutrition support such as oral nutrition supplements, enteral feeding, or parenteral nutrition often needed in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussion of diet with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly recommends not making major dietary changes without consulting the medical team and to follow the guidance of oncology professionals, meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussion of diet with an oncology nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests consulting oncologists/medical team, it does not specifically recommend consulting an oncology nutritionist or registered dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that medical fitness is scored by the oncologist using the ECOG or Karnofsky performance status.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly references ECOG performance status multiple times (e.g., 'ECOG 0 or 1' and 'ECOG ≥2') to guide treatment choice, indicating fitness is assessed via ECOG.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that typically patients who are more medically fit will be offered FOLFIRINOX, whereas those who are more frail but still candidates for treatment will be offered gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states FOLFIRINOX for fit patients and gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel for those not fit for FOLFIRINOX due to poorer performance status or tolerability concerns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that generally FOLFIRINOX is reserved for patients with an ECOG score of 0-1, whereas gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel can be given to ECOG 2 patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifies FOLFIRINOX for ECOG 0–1 and recommends gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel for patients with poor performance status (ECOG ≥2).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the reason that FOLFIRINOX is reserved for patients with good performance status is that it is more intensive and is associated with higher rates of severe side effects such as neutropenia, fatigue, and diarrhea.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes FOLFIRINOX has higher toxicity and lists severe side effects (myelosuppression/akin to neutropenia, neuropathy, diarrhea), framing the need for good performance status.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly list the individual drugs in FOLFIRINOX (5-FU, leucovorin, irinotecan, oxaliplatin) and clarify that nab-paclitaxel is combined with gemcitabine.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists FOLFIRINOX components (5-FU, folinic acid/leucovorin, irinotecan, oxaliplatin) and clearly states nab-paclitaxel is used with gemcitabine.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that there are no head-to-head trials comparing gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel and FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state the absence of head-to-head trials between gemcitabine/nab-paclitaxel and FOLFIRINOX.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention age as a factor influencing the choice of regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly references 'Elderly or frail patients' as more likely to receive gemcitabine+nab-paclitaxel.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention comorbid conditions as a factor in selecting a regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions comorbidities and specific conditions (neuropathy, hearing loss, renal/hepatic dysfunction) as influencing regimen selection.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that resectability is determined by the ability of the surgeon to safely remove the entire tumor and not leave any behind (R0 resection).
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions potentially curative surgery and that tumors can be 'safely removed,' and references R0/R1 categories, but does not explicitly state that achieving an R0 (negative margin) resection—removing the entire tumor without residual—is the determinant of resectability.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that involvement of major blood vessels such as the SMA, SMV, CA, PV are often implicated when a tumor is deemed to not be resectable.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly references SMA, SMV, portal vein, and celiac axis; notes arterial invasion/encasement is generally a contraindication to resection.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that for pancreatic cancer to be resectable, there must not be any distant metastases.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states 'No distant metastases' as part of the definition of resectable disease and lists common metastatic sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that occasionally tumors that contact the veins (PV/SMV) and have less than 180 degrees of involvement can still be resected provided it can be safely removed and the vessel can be reconstructed as needed.
criterion_scores.justification: States that SMV/portal vein involvement <180° may still allow resection in select cases and reiterates this under the NCCN definition; correctly contrasts permissive venous involvement with prohibitive arterial invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that some tumors are deemed to be borderline resectable and that the patient will be recommended to undergo treatment with chemotherapy and/or radiation in order to attempt to down-stage the tumor and make it amenable to resection.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss the 'borderline resectable' category or neoadjuvant chemotherapy/radiation to downstage; only mentions 'borderline cases' in the context of imaging without management implications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including a CT scan.
criterion_scores.justification: Names contrast-enhanced CT as the mainstay for evaluating resectability.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including an MRI.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes MRI as an adjunct for better soft-tissue definition, especially near major vessels.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including a PET scan.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention PET scan.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include imaging modalities that help determine resectability, including an endoscopic ultrasound.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) as helpful for tumor characterization and staging in borderline cases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that family history of pancreas cancer is associated with increased risk.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that having a close relative (parent) with pancreatic cancer increases risk and highlights family history as a significant factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a family history of pancreas cancer is due to inherited gene mutations such as BRCA.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists inherited genetic mutations (e.g., BRCA2, PALB2) as contributors to increased risk and links strong family history to genetic counseling/testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that smoking is a significant modifiable risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: States: 'Smoking: Cigarette smoking is a major risk factor.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Chronic pancreatitis: Long-standing inflammation of the pancreas can increase risk.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that heavy alcohol use can lead to increased risk of pancreas cancer through pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes heavy, long-term alcohol use increases risk and is also a cause of chronic pancreatitis, indicating the pathway.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) among inherited risk factors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists Familial atypical multiple melanoma (FAMM/FAMMM) syndrome as a risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify genetic risk factors, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes hereditary pancreatitis (mentions PRSS1, SPINK1, CTRC, CFTR).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including age.
criterion_scores.justification: States that most cases occur in people over 60.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions both type 1 and type 2 diabetes as associated with higher risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including obesity.
criterion_scores.justification: States that being overweight or obese increases risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including diet.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes high consumption of processed/red meats and low fruits/vegetables may contribute.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include non-hereditary risk factors, including exposure to certain industrial chemicals.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of occupational or industrial chemical exposures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you have a strong family history, discuss with your doctor about screening or genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing family history with a doctor, considering genetic counseling/testing, and discusses screening/surveillance for those with strong family history.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should undergo genetic counseling.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends genetic counseling: includes a dedicated 'Genetic Counseling: Essential' section and advises referral to a genetic counselor/medical geneticist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the type of genetic testing depends on the specific family history or hereditary condition.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states 'The specific test depends on the suspected condition' and emphasizes tailoring to family history and inheritance patterns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that single genes can be tested if there is a known condition associated with a specific genetic disorder.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes 'Single-Gene Testing' and when it is used (when a specific hereditary disease gene is known), with examples such as HTT, CFTR, APC.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a panel of genes can be tested for multiple genes.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Multigene Panel Testing' and explains its use when multiple genes may be implicated (e.g., hereditary cancer panels, cardiomyopathy panels).

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide examples of single gene disorders such as Huntington’s Disease, Cystic Fibrosis, and Sickle Cell.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides Huntington’s disease and cystic fibrosis examples but does not mention sickle cell disease (HBB), so the required set of examples is incomplete.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide examples of panel testing for hereditary cancer and cardiomyopathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions hereditary cancer panels (BRCA1/2, Lynch genes) and cardiomyopathy panels (e.g., LMNA, SCN5A), satisfying both examples.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the types of clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly lists treatment, prevention, diagnostic, and quality-of-life trials, which satisfies describing types of clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that clinical trials are divided into three different phases.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of trial phases or that there are three different phases.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 1 is the first time the drug is tested in humans and is aimed at establishing the safety and dosage.
criterion_scores.justification: Phase 1 is not discussed at all.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 2 tests the effectiveness of the drug and continues to establish its safety.
criterion_scores.justification: Phase 2 is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that phase 3 tests the efficacy of the drug in a larger group of patients and compares it to the current standard of care.
criterion_scores.justification: Phase 3 is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe eligibility criteria for clinical trials, including stage of disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Eligibility is described with examples including type and stage of cancer, previous treatments, age, and overall health.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there can be risks associated with participating in a trial, including potential side effects and lack of efficacy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes that trials may not be better than standard care and could have more side effects; it also mentions extra visits/tests, satisfying risk acknowledgment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing clinical trial options with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises that the loved one’s oncologist can check which trials are appropriate.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include clinicaltrials.gov as a resource for finding clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: ClinicalTrials.gov is explicitly mentioned as a database of studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer support for the diagnosis and how difficult it can be to complete 15 rounds of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: While empathetic, the response does not specifically acknowledge the difficulty of completing 15 rounds of chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must include ClinicalTrials.gov as a resource for finding clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists ClinicalTrials.gov with a direct link and places it first among resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response must provide instructions on using the search by location function on ClinicalTrials.gov.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides clear steps: enter 'pancreatic cancer' and use the 'Location' filter to enter city, state, or ZIP code; also mentions filtering by status and phase.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention the National Cancer Institute (NCI) website and describe using it to search for trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions the NCI clinical trial search tool with link (cancer.gov/.../clinical-trials/search) and describes it as a user-friendly search tool with cancer-specific filters.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention and provide a link to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN) clinical trial finder tool.
criterion_scores.justification: While PanCAN is mentioned with a link to the main site, the specific PanCAN clinical trial finder tool and its direct link are not provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend contacting advocacy organizations for information on clinical trials, including PanCAN.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends 'Check with Cancer Support Organizations' and specifically lists PanCAN with a link and description of patient services that help find trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend contacting advocacy organizations for information on clinical trials, including the American Cancer Society.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions the American Cancer Society with a link and notes it offers guidance and connections to local resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss clinical trial options with their oncology team and consult with a local healthcare provider or oncologist to explore available trials at nearby cancer centers, as well as contact major cancer centers for additional information on clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises asking the doctor/medical team to assess eligibility and provide details, and separately recommends contacting local medical centers and major cancer hospitals’ research departments.

criterion_scores.description: State that family history of pancreatic cancer is associated with increased risk.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that having a first-degree relative with pancreatic cancer increases risk.

criterion_scores.description: State that BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations are genetic risk factors for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions BRCA2 mutations as a genetic risk factor. While BRCA1 is not named, the response identifies BRCA gene mutation risk, satisfying the intent of the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: State that smoking is a significant modifiable risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly identifies cigarette smoking as a significant risk factor, noting it approximately doubles risk.

criterion_scores.description: State that chronic pancreatitis is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists chronic pancreatitis as increasing risk.

criterion_scores.description: State that heavy alcohol use can lead to increased risk of pancreatic cancer through pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains heavy alcohol use can cause chronic pancreatitis, which is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Identify Lynch syndrome as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists Lynch syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: Identify Peutz-Jeghers syndrome as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

criterion_scores.description: Identify Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists familial atypical multiple melanoma (FAMM/FAMMM) syndrome as a risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: Identify hereditary pancreatitis as a genetic risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists hereditary pancreatitis under genetic syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: Include age as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States risk increases with age, especially over 65.

criterion_scores.description: Include diabetes as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists both type 1 and type 2 diabetes as modest risk factors.

criterion_scores.description: Include obesity as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies higher BMI/obesity as associated with increased risk.

criterion_scores.description: Include diet as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes diets high in red/processed meats and low in fruits/vegetables may increase risk.

criterion_scores.description: Include exposure to certain industrial chemicals as a non-hereditary risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions workplace exposures (pesticides, dyes, metal-working chemicals) as possible risk factors.

criterion_scores.description: State that if you have a strong family history, discuss with your doctor about screening or genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises general consultation with a healthcare professional but does not specifically recommend screening or genetic testing for those with a strong family history.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking for a referral from their primary doctor or oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises starting with the primary care physician or oncologist and to ask for a referral.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend using the PanCAN patient services to find a pancreatic cancer specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: PanCAN is specifically recommended, with website, helpline number, and description of services that include connecting patients with specialists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend using the American Cancer Society patient services to find a pancreatic cancer specialist.
criterion_scores.justification: The American Cancer Society is included with its website, a 'Find a Doctor' tool, and helpline number for guidance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can reference the NCI website to look for designated cancer centers that have pancreatic cancer specialists on staff.
criterion_scores.justification: While the NCI website and Cancer Information Service are mentioned, the response does not state using the NCI site to find NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about the nearest cancer center.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific nearest cancer center is provided; the response is generic and asks for location to provide specifics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend checking with their health insurance provider about in-network pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly advises using the insurance directory to find in-network specialists and to call the insurer to verify coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define CA 19-9.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines CA 19-9 as Carbohydrate Antigen 19-9 and a tumor marker; describes it as a glycoprotein found on cell surfaces with typically low levels in healthy individuals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 is a tumor marker produced by cancer cells and measurable in the blood, and describe its use in pancreatic cancer, noting that it can serve as a marker for the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: While it states CA 19-9 is a measurable blood tumor marker and explains its use in monitoring pancreatic cancer, it does not explicitly state that it is produced by cancer cells, which is required by the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response must include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes false positives and lists benign conditions (e.g., liver disease) and other non-cancer causes for elevation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that reference ranges can vary by lab.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that the reference range depends on the laboratory and assay used.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that normal levels are typically less than 37 U/mL but do not rule out cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It does say normal levels do not rule out cancer, but it gives an incorrect reference range and units (3–5 ng/mL) instead of <37 U/mL, so it does not meet the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that levels from 37 to 100 U/mL can be associated with non-cancer conditions such as pancreatitis and bile duct disorders.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of the 37–100 U/mL range or specific reference to pancreatitis or bile duct disorders.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that moderate elevation (100-1000 U/mL) can be concerning for cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not provide the 100–1000 U/mL range or explicitly link that range to concern for cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that levels greater than 1000 U/mL can be suggestive of advanced cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of the >1000 U/mL threshold or its association with advanced cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the use of CA 19-9 in pancreatic cancer, including that it can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies pancreatic cancer as the most common cancer associated with CA 19-9 and discusses its use alongside imaging/biopsy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in other conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists several non-cancer conditions (e.g., inflammatory bowel disease, chronic liver disease, benign tumors) leading to elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for monitoring the effectiveness of pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions serial measurements to monitor response to treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used for detecting recurrence of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that serial measurements can be used to detect recurrence after treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes elevation in other cancers (colorectal, lung, gastric), indicating its use beyond pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in liver disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically mentions chronic liver disease as a non-cancer cause of elevation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated in gallstones.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of gallstones or cholelithiasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be elevated with elevated bilirubin.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of bilirubin or cholestasis-related elevations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that some people with pancreatic cancer have normal CA 19-9 and discusses Lewis-negative status, implying not all pancreatic cancers produce CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions 'Pancreatitis: Both acute and chronic pancreatitis can raise CA 19-9 levels.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with liver diseases like cirrhosis or hepatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: States 'Chronic Liver Disease and Cirrhosis: Liver disease can sometimes cause mild elevations.' Cirrhosis is explicitly included.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with cholestasis or biliary diseases.
