criterion_scores.justification: Includes 'Benign Biliary Obstruction' (e.g., gallstones, strictures) and mentions cholangiocarcinoma and primary sclerosing cholangitis, satisfying biliary/cholestatic causes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with inflammatory bowel disease or gastrointestinal diseases.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists 'Gastric or Intestinal Obstruction' as a gastrointestinal condition associated with elevated CA 19-9, fulfilling the GI disease component (IBD not required if GI disease is present).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CA 19-9 can be elevated with infections or other inflammatory conditions.
criterion_scores.justification: Contains 'Inflammatory Conditions: Chronic inflammation in the pancreas or biliary tree may lead to elevated levels,' covering inflammatory conditions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be a marker of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States CA 19-9 is most commonly associated with pancreatic cancer and is used to monitor treatment response/progression, indicating marker use.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 can be used in other cancers.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple other cancers (gastric, cholangiocarcinoma, gallbladder, colorectal, ovarian, lung, breast) associated with elevated CA 19-9.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that CA 19-9 is not produced by all pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state that some pancreatic cancers/patients (e.g., Lewis antigen–negative) do not produce CA 19-9; genetic baseline variation is mentioned but not non-production.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing weight loss with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises consulting the oncology team and a registered dietitian, emphasizing coordination with the care team before making changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be taken to help with the absorption of nutrients from foods.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that pancreatic exocrine insufficiency is common and that doctors may prescribe pancreatic enzyme supplements to help with digestion and nutrient absorption.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that nutritional strategies can be employed, such as focusing on small, frequent meals and nutrient-rich foods, and should recommend including calorie-dense and protein-rich foods in the diet.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends small, frequent meals, high-calorie/high-protein foods, liquid calories, and easy-to-eat options, clearly meeting the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that medications for managing nausea can be helpful.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Manage Side Effects,' it notes that medications can help with nausea and vomiting.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to chemotherapy side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple causes including treatment side effects such as chemotherapy and radiation, appetite loss, metabolic changes, increased energy expenditure, and digestive issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state there are many causes of weight loss in patients with pancreatic cancer, including weight loss related to pancreatic enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly identifies pancreatic exocrine insufficiency as a cause of weight loss and discusses addressing malabsorption with pancreatic enzymes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include unintentional weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states "Unintended weight loss – Losing weight without trying."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include jaundice.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists "Jaundice – Yellowing of the skin and eyes."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include new onset diabetes.
criterion_scores.justification: States "New-onset diabetes" and explains tumor disrupting insulin production.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a symptom of pancreatic cancer can include abdominal pain.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes "Pain in the abdomen or back – Dull pain felt in the upper abdomen."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer can be difficult to detect early.
criterion_scores.justification: Opening sentence states it is "difficult to detect early" and reiterates "Early detection is challenging."

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer does not cause symptoms until the disease is advanced.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that symptoms typically do not appear until advanced disease; instead notes subtle, nonspecific early symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the reason for jaundice is the blockade of bile ducts.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains jaundice occurs due to the tumor affecting the bile duct, implying obstruction.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that loss of appetite can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists "Poor appetite" explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that abdominal bloating or indigestion can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions "indigestion" as a symptom.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that foul-smelling stools or steatorrhea can be a symptom.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions "steatorrhea, or fatty stools."

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference the American Cancer Society information page on symptoms of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No reference to the American Cancer Society provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that most pancreatic cancer cases are sporadic and not hereditary.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that pancreatic cancer is not typically hereditary and that ~95% of cases are sporadic.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are hereditary conditions that can lead to pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly notes that a small percentage are linked to inherited mutations and lists several hereditary syndromes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a strong family history is a significant risk factor.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions strong family history (multiple relatives affected) as a risk consideration and recommends genetic counseling/testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including familial pancreatic cancer syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention familial pancreatic cancer syndrome specifically. PanIN is incorrectly listed as a hereditary syndrome and does not satisfy this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists BRCA1 and BRCA2 as associated with increased pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Lynch syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) as increasing pancreatic cancer risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and identifies the associated gene (LKB1/STK11).

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies the syndrome (FAMMM) as 'familial atypical multiple melanoma and pancreatic cancer syndrome' and notes CDKN2A; despite slight naming variation, the intent is clear.

criterion_scores.description: The response should identify hereditary pancreatic cancer syndromes, including hereditary pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically lists hereditary pancreatitis and relevant genes (PRSS1, SPINK1, CFTR).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult an oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing with a healthcare provider or genetic counselor but does not specifically recommend consulting an oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if you are concerned about your risk of pancreatic cancer, you should consult a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends genetic counseling and testing and suggests speaking with a genetic counselor.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that routine screening is not recommended for the general population.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly emphasizes that surveillance is considered only for individuals at significantly increased risk and is recommended only for those at elevated risk, which explicitly excludes the general population.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention MRI as a surveillance modality for high-risk individuals.
criterion_scores.justification: MRI is highlighted as the most sensitive modality for high-risk surveillance with details on timing and frequency.

criterion_scores.description: The response must specify that surveillance typically starts around age 50 and continues annually.
criterion_scores.justification: The response specifies annual surveillance and provides start ages including 40–50 for strong family history, which aligns with the concept of starting around age 50.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that the evidence for screening/surveillance is not well established and mention the risk of overdiagnosis leading to unnecessary stress and procedures.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes the evidence base is limited (expert opinion, small studies, no RCTs proving survival benefit) and mentions false positives causing additional tests, anxiety, and unnecessary surgery.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that people at high risk may benefit from screening.
criterion_scores.justification: States surveillance is recommended for those at significantly elevated risk, implying benefit for high-risk individuals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a significant family history of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes strong family history as a high-risk category and details thresholds for testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a known genetic syndrome.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple genetic syndromes (BRCA1/2, PALB2, CDKN2A, STK11, ATM, Lynch) as high-risk.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define people at high risk of pancreatic cancer to include those with a history of chronic pancreatitis.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly includes chronic pancreatitis as a high-risk factor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include EUS as a screening modality to detect pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) as a surveillance option, particularly when MRI is contraindicated or to evaluate lesions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a doctor.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends individualized decision-making with multidisciplinary input (surgeon, gastroenterologist) and a thorough discussion of risks and benefits, which constitutes discussing with a doctor.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend people discuss the risks and benefits of screening with a genetic counselor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends referral for genetic counseling and includes genetic counseling in decision-making.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include surgery as a potential treatment modality for resectable pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly describes surgical resection (Whipple, distal pancreatectomy) as potentially curative for localized/resectable disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should specify that chemotherapy is the backbone of treatment for metastatic or unresectable pancreatic cancer, with main regimens being FOLFIRINOX or Gemcitabine + Nab-Paclitaxel.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists metastatic chemotherapy options including FOLFIRINOX and gemcitabine + nab-paclitaxel, indicating their use in advanced disease.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include radiation as a potential treatment option for localized pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes EBRT and chemoradiation for locally advanced/unresectable disease and mentions SBRT, fulfilling radiation as an option for localized settings.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: States up front that treatment depends on the stage and repeatedly differentiates approaches by resectable vs locally advanced vs metastatic.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the co-morbidities of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'overall health' but does not explicitly state comorbidities as a determinant as required by the rubric.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the treatment of pancreatic cancer depends on the functional status of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of performance/functional status (e.g., ECOG) as a factor in treatment selection.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include immunotherapy, noting its role is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state the MSI-H/dMMR limitation; instead suggests pembrolizumab + chemotherapy for first-line metastatic disease, which is not standard for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include targeted therapy such as PARPi for patients with BRCA mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib) may be considered for patients with BRCA mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should introduce the concept of clinical trials and their role in the management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly highlights clinical trials as an option and discusses ongoing research and novel approaches.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 0 is a pre-cancer state, also known as pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ.
criterion_scores.justification: The response labels Stage 0 as 'Non-invasive papillary mucinous neoplasm' and does not mention carcinoma in situ or pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN). This is inaccurate and omits the required terminology.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage 1 cancer is when the cancer is confined to the pancreas and has not spread to lymph nodes or distant sites.
criterion_scores.justification: For Stage IA and IB, the response explicitly states the tumor is confined to the pancreas with no lymph node or distant spread, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1a is when the tumor is 2cm or smaller.
criterion_scores.justification: Stage IA is correctly described as a tumor 2 cm or smaller.

criterion_scores.description: The response should note that stage 1b is when the tumor is larger than 2cm.
criterion_scores.justification: Stage IB is correctly described as larger than 2 cm.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage II is when the cancer is growing into nearby tissues and into lymph nodes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states Stage IIA and IIB have not spread to lymph nodes, which contradicts the requirement (and AJCC definitions for IIB). It does not acknowledge lymph node involvement in Stage II.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage III is when the cancer is locally advanced and involves surrounding structures.
criterion_scores.justification: Stage III is described only as involving nearby lymph nodes. Locally advanced disease with involvement of surrounding vascular structures is incorrectly placed under 'Stage IVA,' not Stage III.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that stage IV is when the cancer has spread to other organs or sites.
criterion_scores.justification: Stage IV is correctly defined as distant metastasis to organs such as liver, lungs, or peritoneum.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a description of the T, N, M staging system.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains that AJCC TNM considers tumor size/extent (T), lymph node involvement (N), and distant metastasis (M).

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic cancer is categorized by resectability.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of resectability categories (resectable, borderline resectable, locally advanced/unresectable, metastatic).

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy is a common side effect from the oxaliplatin in FOLFIRINOX.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that neuropathy is a known side effect, particularly from the oxaliplatin component of FOLFIRINOX.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the oncologist can ‘hold’ or temporarily stop oxaliplatin to manage neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions a 'treatment break' (temporarily stopping treatment), it does not specifically state holding or temporarily stopping oxaliplatin itself.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by dose reduction.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly states that the dose of oxaliplatin can be reduced to manage neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by schedule modification.
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes 'treatment break' (temporarily stopping treatment) as a strategy, which constitutes schedule modification to manage neuropathy.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen.
criterion_scores.justification: The response suggests switching from FOLFIRINOX to alternative chemotherapy regimens if neuropathy is not tolerable.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed by switching to an alternate regimen, including gemcitabine-based therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Gemcitabine-based regimens (e.g., Gemcitabine + Abraxane) are explicitly mentioned as alternatives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including gabapentin.
criterion_scores.justification: Gabapentin is explicitly listed among supportive medications for neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including SNRIs.
criterion_scores.justification: Duloxetine, an SNRI, is specifically mentioned as a supportive medication.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that neuropathy from oxaliplatin can be managed using supportive medications, including pregabalin.
criterion_scores.justification: Pregabalin is explicitly listed among supportive medications for neuropathic pain.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing medication side effects with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly encourages open discussion with the oncology team about severity of neuropathy, treatment adjustments, and supportive measures.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be informed about the aim of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises understanding the 'Purpose of the Trial' (e.g., new drug, combination, method, or diagnostic), clearly addressing the trial's aim.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential benefits of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Risks and Benefits,' it discusses 'Potential Benefits' and whether the new treatment could help, fulfilling the benefits criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should understand the potential risks of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: It addresses 'Known Risks and Side Effects,' including short- and long-term effects and unknown risks, meeting the risks criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Eligibility Criteria' section highlights strict requirements (stage, prior treatments, overall health) and ensuring the patient meets them, covering inclusion/exclusion awareness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the time commitments associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: The 'Location and Logistics' section asks about travel, visit frequency, and explicitly mentions 'time and resource commitments,' addressing time commitments clearly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should be aware of the costs associated with participating in the trial.
criterion_scores.justification: Under 'Ask Questions,' it includes 'Will insurance cover the costs, or will there be additional expenses?' directly addressing cost considerations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding the phase of the clinical trial.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly discusses 'Trial Phase' (Phase I, II, III) and what each implies, recommending understanding the phase.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend understanding if there are crossover options.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions randomization, placebo, and single-arm design, it does not address crossover options or switching arms upon progression.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used before surgery to help shrink borderline resectable tumors, with the goal of increasing the likelihood of achieving a complete resection in the localized setting.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly describes neoadjuvant/induction radiation before surgery to shrink tumors that are close to vessels or otherwise not safely resectable, to make surgery more feasible.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used for locally advanced or unresectable tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: It states radiation may be used for locally advanced disease that cannot be safely removed with surgery and discusses chemoradiation in locally advanced cancers.

criterion_scores.description: Radiation can be used in the palliative setting to relieve symptoms in patients with advanced or metastatic disease.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly identifies palliative radiation for symptom relief (pain, jaundice, bowel obstruction) when cancer has spread or surgery isn’t an option.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the stage of the disease.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that decisions depend on many factors including the stage of cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Pancreatic cancer treatment plans are determined by the overall health of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists overall health as a factor in deciding on radiation use.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to sterilize vessel margins.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions adjuvant radiation after positive margins and proximity to vessels preoperatively, it does not specifically state the goal of sterilizing vessel margins.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to delay disease progression.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes chemoradiation is used in locally advanced cancers to improve the chance of controlling the cancer, which reflects delaying disease progression.

criterion_scores.description: The goal of radiation in the localized setting can be to prevent local recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that postoperative (adjuvant) radiation may be given after surgery to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back, aligning with prevention of local recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic cancer leads to enzyme deficiency.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that pancreatic cancer can affect the pancreas's ability to make enzymes and that the pancreas may not release enough enzymes if damaged by cancer, clearly indicating enzyme deficiency due to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how enzyme deficiency can lead to problems with digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that enzymes break down fats, proteins, and carbohydrates, and that insufficient enzymes lead to trouble digesting meals, with symptoms like bloating, pain, and weight loss, linking deficiency to impaired digestion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements are used to replace the enzymes.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that pancreatic enzyme supplements are medications that help replace the enzymes the pancreas cannot make enough of.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme supplements can improve digestion.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that the supplements help break down food so nutrients can be absorbed more effectively and can help manage digestive symptoms and improve nutrition, indicating improved digestion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer is associated with an increased risk of developing blood clots.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly links cancer to increased clot risk, stating that tumors release substances that make blood more likely to clot and that treatments such as surgery can increase clot risk. This clearly communicates that cancer is associated with an increased risk of blood clots.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients with pancreatic cancer are at increased risk of developing a blood clot.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states, "People with pancreatic cancer have a higher risk of developing blood clots," directly fulfilling the criterion with clear and accurate information specific to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that second opinions can be obtained at any time, including after diagnosis, before starting treatment, during treatment, or when considering clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response says, 'You can (and many patients do) seek a second opinion at any stage,' and gives examples (after diagnosis, before major treatment). While it does not list 'during treatment' or 'clinical trials' specifically, the 'at any stage' statement explicitly covers any time.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mentions second opinions are particularly helpful after the initial diagnosis and before starting treatment, as well as when the initial treatment is no longer effective.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions after initial diagnosis and before major treatment but does not mention the scenario when initial treatment is no longer effective.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mentions that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty regarding the diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states, 'If you’re unsure about the diagnosis,' indicating a second opinion is helpful for diagnostic uncertainty.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mentions that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty regarding staging.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention staging explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly mentions that a second opinion is helpful if there is uncertainty regarding the treatment plan.
criterion_scores.justification: States, 'If you’re unsure about ... the recommended treatment plan,' directly addressing uncertainty about the plan.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that second opinions can be obtained at specialized referral centers, such as cancer centers with expertise in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises seeking second opinions at 'top cancer centers' and 'academic or tertiary care centers' with multidisciplinary teams, which are specialized referral centers.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly states that they should look up NCI-designated cancer centers specifically.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions the National Cancer Institute website but does not specifically instruct to look up 'NCI-designated cancer centers.'

criterion_scores.description: Mentions major academic hospitals as a resource for finding pancreatic cancer specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends 'academic or tertiary care centers,' which are major academic hospitals.

criterion_scores.description: Mentions that the NCCN guidelines for Pancreatic Adenocarcinoma recommend evaluation at high volume centers.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of NCCN guidelines or recommendations about evaluation at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is currently limited to patients with mismatch repair deficiency or high microsatellite instability.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly notes that pancreatic cancers with MSI-H or mismatch repair deficiency may benefit and cites FDA approval in this subset, emphasizing the limited applicability.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immunotherapy is an ongoing area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that research is advancing rapidly and describes ongoing efforts to make tumors more visible to the immune system.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there may be clinical trial options exploring novel immunotherapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses ongoing clinical trials, combination strategies, and cancer vaccines, and recommends discussing trial participation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that immune checkpoint blockade is only approved for patients with metastatic disease in certain situations.
criterion_scores.justification: It states FDA approval of pembrolizumab for metastatic pancreatic cancer with MSI-H/dMMR, conveying that approval applies in specific metastatic scenarios.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pembrolizumab is approved for patients whose tumors are TMB high.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention the tumor-agnostic approval for TMB-high tumors; it only references MSI-H/dMMR and PD-L1.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend asking their oncology team about testing for eligibility for immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises discussing with the oncologist and specifically mentions reviewing the tumor’s genetic profile to determine suitability for immunotherapy or clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they should consult with their oncologist on the potential next steps.
criterion_scores.justification: The response repeatedly emphasizes discussing options with the oncologist and explicitly advises scheduling a meeting and considering a second opinion, clearly meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest alternative standard of care therapies.
criterion_scores.justification: It outlines multiple alternative standard-of-care options after progression, including second-line chemotherapy, targeted therapy, immunotherapy (when markers present), radiation, and in rare cases surgery, indicating the oncologist may suggest these.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the oncologist may suggest clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: There is a dedicated section on clinical trials stating the patient may be eligible and that these can offer access to new treatments, fully satisfying this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that re-biopsy of the disease could reveal targetable mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response recommends tumor profiling/NGS to look for targets and mentions biopsy for reassessment, it does not explicitly state that a re-biopsy could reveal targetable mutations or link re-biopsy to molecular testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend supportive care and symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes a thorough section on symptom management and palliative care, end-of-life planning, and supportive resources, meeting this criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is no approved CAR-T cell therapy for pancreatic cancer at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that CAR-T cell therapy is not currently an approved or standard treatment for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe CAR-T cells.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not explain what CAR-T cells are (e.g., engineered T cells expressing a chimeric antigen receptor to target tumor antigens). It only vaguely mentions immune cells being redirected, without describing CAR-T specifically.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are being studied in clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly mentions ongoing clinical trials investigating CAR-T cell therapy for pancreatic cancer and suggests ClinicalTrials.gov for finding trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that CAR-T cells are approved for the treatment of other types of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response accurately states that CAR-T cell therapy is approved for certain blood cancers, including leukemias, lymphomas, and multiple myeloma.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice is considered when the medical team estimates a life expectancy of 6 months or less.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that hospice is generally considered when the patient has a prognosis of six months or less to live, if the illness follows its usual course.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the aim of hospice is to maximize quality of life and focus on addressing symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly emphasizes comfort, quality of life, and symptom management (e.g., pain, nausea, fatigue).

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that hospice can take place in the home, a nursing home, or in a dedicated hospice facility.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions home, hospice facility, and hospital, but does not mention nursing home as a setting, which the criterion specifically requires.

criterion_scores.description: The answer should start with an expression of sympathy and support.
criterion_scores.justification: Begins with a compassionate acknowledgment of the difficult situation and supportive tone.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hospice care.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a clear definition of hospice care as specialized care focused on comfort rather than curative treatment for those in the final stages of serious illness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including emotional and spiritual support.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically notes emotional and spiritual support and includes chaplains/spiritual advisors as part of the team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what hospice care covers, including bereavement support.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions bereavement counselors and support for the family.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that fatigue is a common side effect of chemotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that severe fatigue during chemotherapy is common.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing symptoms with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple clear recommendations to consult the oncology team and tailor care with them.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that optimizing nutrition and hydration can help manage fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends balanced nutrition and a dietitian but does not mention hydration.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend good sleep hygiene.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a dedicated section on rest and sleep hygiene with concrete tips.

criterion_scores.description: The response should discuss potential causes for fatigue, including the effect of the cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions anemia, medication side effects, pain, anxiety, and depression but does not explicitly state that the cancer itself can cause fatigue.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that light physical activity can improve fatigue.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that light exercise such as short walks can reduce fatigue.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend medication review.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises asking about medication side effects and potential adjustments to the chemotherapy regimen.

criterion_scores.description: State that alternative treatments like cannabis oil have not been proven to help patients with pancreatic cancer live longer or cure them.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states there is limited rigorous scientific evidence that cannabis oil is effective for pancreatic cancer in humans and that preclinical findings have not been conclusively replicated in human trials, which conveys that it is not proven to treat/cure or improve survival.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is sometimes used to manage cancer-related symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes that some people use cannabis oil to manage nausea, pain, loss of appetite, and anxiety related to cancer or its treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend discussing the use of cannabis oil with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly advises discussing any complementary or alternative treatment, including cannabis oil, with the oncologist or healthcare team.

criterion_scores.description: Describe cannabis oil.
criterion_scores.justification: While not a full formal definition, the response explains that cannabis contains compounds like THC and CBD with therapeutic effects, implicitly characterizing cannabis oil as a source of these cannabinoids.

criterion_scores.description: State that cannabis oil is not used as an anti-cancer treatment per guidelines.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not reference clinical guidelines or explicitly state that guidelines do not recommend cannabis oil as an anti-cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including drug interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions potential interactions with other medications.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists side effects such as dizziness, mood changes, and increased anxiety.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including variation in quality.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes concerns about product purity, consistency, and accurate dosing when obtained outside regulated systems.

criterion_scores.description: Describe risks of using cannabis oil, including legal concerns.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses legal variability by region and potential legal consequences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that lack of appetite is a common side effect of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that loss of appetite is very common in people with pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient should consult with their oncologist, who may refer them to a registered dietitian, oncology nutritionist, and/or palliative care physician to address symptoms and optimize supportive care.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises discussing changes with his medical team and mentions the oncology team specifically, and suggests consulting a cancer care dietitian or nutritionist. Although palliative care is not mentioned, the criterion allows 'and/or,' and the oncologic and dietitian components are present.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that pancreatic enzyme replacement can be pursued.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (e.g., PERT, enzymes like Creon) is included.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try smaller meals.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends small meals: 'Offer small amounts of food more often instead of large meals.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try more frequent meals.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends eating 'more often,' i.e., frequent meals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that the patient can try nutritional replacement shakes.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests smoothies and milkshakes with protein powder, which function as nutritional/meal-replacement shakes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that appetite stimulants can also be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking about medications that can help stimulate appetite.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that cancer itself can cause loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that loss of appetite is very common in people with pancreatic cancer, indicating the disease itself can cause it.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that chemotherapy can cause nausea and loss of appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions 'side effects of treatment' causing symptoms but does not specifically mention chemotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that bloating can decrease appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: Bloating is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include that pancreatic enzyme deficiency can cause decreased appetite.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of pancreatic enzyme insufficiency or its impact on appetite.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can start with their primary doctor who can help refer to the most local community hospital with oncology services.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises talking to a primary care physician or local oncologist, but it does not explicitly state that the primary doctor can refer to the most local community hospital with oncology services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that if they are able to travel, then major cancer centers offer consultations which can also be done as telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly recommends consultation at larger/major cancer centers if travel is possible and notes that many offer telehealth/teleconsultations. It also provides examples of major centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that patients can search for NCI-designated cancer centers to find the closest one to them, and explicitly mention that both oncologists and palliative care teams often offer virtual visits through telemedicine or telehealth consultations.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of NCI-designated cancer centers or searching for them, and it does not explicitly state that both oncologists and palliative care teams offer virtual visits.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend reaching out to regional cancer centers, including examples or resources for finding such centers.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends identifying the nearest major cancer/academic medical center and provides examples (e.g., Mayo Clinic, MD Anderson, Dana-Farber, UCSF, University of Michigan).

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that specialists will often partner with local oncologists to coordinate care.
criterion_scores.justification: It states that a local oncologist can coordinate care and consult with specialists remotely and implement treatment plans from major centers, demonstrating partnership and coordinated care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with insurance coverage.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathetic language acknowledging the stress and difficulty of insurance denials and expresses sympathy directly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that they can work with the hospital’s financial counselor or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends seeking help from social workers at the hospital or cancer center for insurance and financial challenges.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state the person should work with their oncology team to help with the denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises obtaining a medical necessity letter from the oncologist or treating physician and gathering relevant medical records, indicating collaboration with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include contacting the insurance company to understand the reason for denial.
criterion_scores.justification: Instructs to request a detailed explanation from the insurer (EOB/denial letter) and review policy terms to understand the reason for denial.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state one option for remedy is filing an appeal.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes the internal appeals process, persistence through multiple levels, and mentions external review as an additional step.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define high-volume centers as those performing at least 40 or 50 Whipple procedures per year.
criterion_scores.justification: The response describes high-volume centers as doing a large number of surgeries but does not specify a numeric threshold (≥40–50 Whipple procedures/year) or mention Whipple procedures explicitly.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have significantly lower mortality rates and higher overall survival rates for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions higher survival rates, it does not explicitly state lower mortality rates. The rubric requires both lower mortality and higher survival.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have significantly lower complication rates.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that studies show lower complication rates and reiterates lower rates of complications at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that at a high-volume center, the surgeon is more likely to be a specialist in pancreas surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes more experience with complex cases but does not explicitly state that surgeons are pancreas surgery specialists or more likely to be such specialists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers often have access to clinical trials.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states that patients may have access to clinical trials at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that high-volume centers have access to the latest treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions access to the latest technology, techniques, and contrasts that local hospitals may have less access to the latest treatments and technologies, implying high-volume centers do.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including travel time.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly discusses travel distance and the need to consider how much travel is involved for a distant center.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state disadvantages of going to a high-volume center, including more complicated logistics.
criterion_scores.justification: It references 'Travel and Logistics' and the need for family support at a distant center, indicating more complicated logistics.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly mentions the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network (PanCAN), including its Patient and Family Resource Hub and financial guidance, as a resource.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention CancerCare as a resource for financial assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: CancerCare is specifically listed, described as providing financial assistance for transportation, home care, and more, with a link to cancercare.org.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the American Cancer Society as a resource for financial assistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly advises that social workers at the hospital or cancer center can help connect patients with financial assistance and tailored support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should offer sympathy for the stressful situation dealing with financial burden during cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing financial concerns with a financial counselor.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers the emergency department and calling 988 if the patient experiences thoughts of harming themself or others.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly suggests asking the loved one’s oncologist specific questions about stage, spread, molecular features, treatments, and clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that many aspects of a patient’s health impact their prognosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions age, overall health, and genetic factors as patient-specific factors influencing outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines overall survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines overall survival as the percentage alive at a certain time after diagnosis, which is an acceptable lay definition consistent with clinical usage.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines progression-free survival as it is used in clinical research.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines PFS (and DFS) as the percentage without cancer progression or return at a certain time after treatment, reflecting the core concept of PFS.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that overall survival and progression-free survival are typically reported as medians.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of medians or that OS/PFS are commonly summarized as median times.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the above biostatistics terms (overall survival, progression-free survival, and median) in laymen’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides lay explanations for OS and PFS but does not mention or explain the term median.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that survival data is best reported in terms of the stage of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly emphasizes that stage (early vs metastatic) strongly affects survival rates, indicating survival data should be considered by stage.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of applying reported statistics to patients’ individual cases.
criterion_scores.justification: States that statistics are averages, individual variation exists, and numbers don’t predict an individual’s outcome.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the difference between overall survival and progression-free survival.
criterion_scores.justification: By defining OS (alive) versus PFS (no progression/return), it differentiates the two endpoints.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival is influenced by tumor characteristics such as genetic mutations (BRCA, KRAS), size, and location.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions genetic or molecular features generally but does not cite specific mutations (e.g., BRCA, KRAS) nor tumor size or location.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that survival depends on treatments received (chemotherapy, surgery, targeted therapy, no treatment, etc.) and treatment response.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that survival varies with treatments (surgery, chemotherapy) but does not explicitly mention treatment response.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that new treatments and advancements are being developed all the time, and these could potentially improve outcomes in the future.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions 'talk to his doctors' and 'medical team' but does not explicitly recommend discussing with the patient's oncologist.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that a liquid biopsy is a blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states 'a simple blood test' and describes a 'blood draw.'

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that liquid biopsies involve analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) from blood samples.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions 'Fragments of tumor DNA (ctDNA – circulating tumor DNA)' found in the bloodstream.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains there are many different tests which evaluate various things including circulating tumor DNA, circulating tumor cells, and proteins in the blood.
criterion_scores.justification: While ctDNA and CTCs are listed, proteins are not explicitly mentioned; 'other biomarkers' is too vague for full credit.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that liquid biopsies do not replace tissue biopsies in the diagnosis of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States they are 'used alongside, not instead of, tissue biopsies.'

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies must be interpreted by a medical professional.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes results can be hard to interpret but does not state that a medical professional must interpret them.

criterion_scores.description: The response says the results of liquid biopsies may be helpful when combined with imaging and pathology results.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit mention of combining results with imaging or pathology; only 'other tests' is referenced.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions there are liquid biopsies in various stages of development for different kinds of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of development stages or variation by cancer type.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the limitations of liquid biopsies, including sensitivity, false positives, and cost.
criterion_scores.justification: While limitations are noted, false positives and cost are not mentioned; sensitivity is not explicitly addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response says there are currently no FDA approved liquid biopsies for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of FDA approval status for pancreatic cancer liquid biopsies.

criterion_scores.description: The response says health insurance may not pay for these tests.
criterion_scores.justification: Insurance coverage is not addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response says liquid biopsies may be able to identify genetic mutations present in the cancer which can help to guide treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states they can 'identify genetic mutations... which may suggest which treatments are most likely to work.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that liquid biopsies are noninvasive and can expedite testing because there is no need to retrieve archival blocks or arrange for a new biopsy.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions less invasive and potentially faster results, but does not specify the reason (no need for archival blocks/new biopsy).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that copy-number changes may be more difficult to assess in cfDNA, and fusion testing may be more limited in common cfDNA tests currently used.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of copy-number or fusion testing limitations in cfDNA.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that this is still under active research and not yet standard of care for all cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not state that liquid biopsy is under active research or not standard of care for all patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers the costs of travel.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises investigating total cost including travel expenses and mentions accommodation and transport needs.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers logistics of travel, including the need for passports and/or visas.

criterion_scores.description: The response considers language and cultural barriers.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends considering if the patient is medically safe for travel.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching the quality of healthcare in the intended destination.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends researching hospitals/physicians with pancreatic cancer expertise, multidisciplinary care, and accreditation/standards.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing all travel plans with a medical professional prior to leaving.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states to consult the mother's oncologist to discuss treatment abroad and to get a second opinion.

criterion_scores.description: The response says that delaying the start of treatment for pancreatic cancer can be harmful.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends researching pancreatic cancer outcomes in the intended destination as compared to her home country.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends understanding the patient’s treatment options, including clinical trials, which may be available in her home country before making travel plans.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention considerations related to insurance funding.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses checking insurance coverage for treatment abroad and mentions medical evacuation provisions and financial assistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider local accommodations when traveling abroad for treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention to consider challenges with follow-up care when traveling abroad for treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that immunizations and infection prevention are important, especially for immunosuppressed patients.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that telemedicine and remote support can be leveraged for follow-up, symptom management, and multidisciplinary care, reducing the need for frequent travel and facilitating access to expertise at high-volume centers.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that bowel changes, including diarrhea, nausea, and constipation, are common among patients undergoing treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions diarrhea and constipation but does not state that nausea is common; it only references persistent vomiting as a severe symptom.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that chemotherapy, radiation therapy, surgery, and other treatments such as pain medications can impact the bowels.
criterion_scores.justification: Chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery are mentioned, but pain medications/opioids are not referenced.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing specific concerns with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises talking to the oncology team/healthcare provider about these symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends keeping a log of events related to food intake, fluid intake, and bowel symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing the above log with the patient’s healthcare team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that pre-existing conditions can cause bowel changes unrelated to cancer or cancer treatment.
