criterion_scores.description: Recommend consulting oncology team and oncology pharmacist before starting new medications or supplements to avoid interactions.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages communication with the medical team but does not specifically advise consulting an oncology pharmacist or avoiding new meds/supplements without review.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that sometimes dialysis may be indicated if there is severe kidney injury related to treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Dialysis is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend staying well hydrated and maintaining adequate nutrition during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides dietary modification guidance but does not explicitly recommend staying well hydrated or maintaining adequate nutrition intake.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of genetic mutations in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains that cancer cells acquire DNA mutations during division, some of which confer advantages (faster growth, metastasis, treatment resistance), and that these mutations drive tumor evolution.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how cancer treatment applies selective pressure on cancer cells, allowing those that harbor certain characteristics that confer resistance to therapy a survival advantage.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes natural selection in tumors and specifically notes that treatment can lead to relapse because remaining cells have evolved resistance, implying treatment as a selective pressure favoring resistant clones.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that after certain treatments, tumor cells susceptible to that treatment will have died while those resistant to the treatment survive, making the residual cancer fundamentally different from the original cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that after treatment the cancer may come back because remaining cells have evolved resistance, indicating selective survival of resistant populations and a changed post-treatment tumor composition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how genetic mutations can cause cancer cells to resist certain treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions that mutations can make cancer cells resistant to chemotherapy or targeted therapies and discusses monitoring for new resistance mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the heterogeneous cellular make-up of pancreatic cancer at baseline.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions tumor heterogeneity in general but does not specifically address baseline heterogeneity unique to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mesenchymal-epithelial transition, including triggers for this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention mesenchymal-epithelial transition (MET) or its triggers (e.g., microenvironmental cues, hypoxia, TGF-β).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe methods for evaluating tumor evolution over time, including circulating tumor DNA and/or traditional biopsy of the primary tumor or metastatic lesion.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers serial biopsies, genetic sequencing, and liquid biopsies detecting tumor DNA in blood for longitudinal monitoring.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that tumor evolution is when the cancer changes and adapts over time.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly defines tumor evolution as tumor cells changing and adapting over time within the body.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define complementary therapies, including supportive and integrative therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: The response references complementary therapies but does not define the term nor explain supportive care or integrative therapy concepts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define aromatherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Aromatherapy is clearly defined as the use of essential oils via inhalation or topical application to promote relaxation, reduce stress, or alleviate symptoms like nausea.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that any substances that are ingested or applied to the body can cause a reaction, such as an allergic reaction, and may be difficult to tell if the patient’s reaction is from the complementary therapy or the cancer treatment itself. For this reason, these complementary therapies should be used with caution.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions allergic/skin reactions and advises caution, it does not state that reactions may be hard to distinguish from cancer treatment side effects, which is required.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform patients that complementary therapies do not treat cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states aromatherapy is not a substitute for conventional therapy, conveying that it does not treat cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform patients that some complementary therapies may help with symptoms related to their cancer diagnosis, such as stress or insomnia.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes potential benefits for stress, anxiety, mood, and possibly nausea, satisfying the symptom-support criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient inquire with their oncology team if there are practitioners of complementary therapies that they trust, or can place a referral to.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises discussing with the oncology team and suggests consulting a certified aromatherapist, but does not recommend asking the oncology team for trusted practitioners or referrals.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide website links to informational pages from cancer societies such as NCI or PanCAN.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes links to the NCI and the American Cancer Society, meeting the requirement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should strongly recommend that the patient discuss any complementary therapies they are considering with their oncology team to ensure there are no harmful interactions with their cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It strongly urges discussing any complementary therapy with the oncology team before starting and mentions potential interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that aromatherapy is safest when used through inhalation and that oils must be appropriately prepared.
criterion_scores.justification: Although proper dilution is mentioned and inhalation is discussed, it does not explicitly state that inhalation is the safest route.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that essential oils on the skin should be used with caution due to the risk of worsening skin irritation from chemotherapy or radiation.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes potential skin irritation with topical use but does not explicitly link this risk to worsening irritation from chemotherapy or radiation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define metabolism in humans.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines metabolism as the set of chemical reactions that convert nutrients into energy and building blocks, which is an accurate, human-applicable definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the Warburg Effect.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions the Warburg effect and describes it as increased glucose uptake with inefficient use of glucose by cancer cells, which constitutes a basic description.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about glucose, amino acid, and lipid metabolism in cancer cells, specifically in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses increased glucose uptake and altered amino acid and lipid metabolism in cancer cells generally, but does not provide pancreatic cancer–specific metabolic features.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that changes in metabolism can alter sensitivity to cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that metabolic state can affect response to standard treatments and that some changes can confer resistance or vulnerability.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not recommend specific diets for the management of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not recommend any specific diet; advises a balanced diet unless directed by the healthcare team and emphasizes uncertainty about dietary impacts on cancer growth.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not indicate that restrictive diets, such as the ketogenic diet or intermittent fasting, should be started by patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention or advocate for restrictive diets such as ketogenic diets or intermittent fasting.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss diet with their oncologist and request a referral to a nutritionist if they are interested in learning more.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends speaking with a registered oncology dietitian and engaging the oncology team, fulfilling the intent to involve clinicians and nutrition experts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there is not any current evidence for dietary interventions to alter the metabolism of the cancer and improve treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: States there is ongoing debate about dietary impacts but does not explicitly state that there is no current evidence for dietary interventions to improve treatment via metabolic alteration.

criterion_scores.description: List causes of eye problems related to cancer and/or treatment, including chemotherapy-induced optic neuropathy, immunotherapy-related inflammation, bleeding, cataracts, dry eye, metastatic disease to the brain or eye, and infections.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions chemotherapy-related dry eyes, uveitis, and glaucoma, but does not address chemotherapy-induced optic neuropathy, immunotherapy-related inflammation, bleeding, cataracts, metastatic disease to the brain or eye, or infections.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that chemotherapy can lead to eye dryness and irritations.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that chemotherapy drugs can cause eye-related side effects including dry eyes and lists irritation-like symptoms (e.g., sensitivity to light).

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that the use of steroids can lead to an increase in cataracts or glaucoma.
criterion_scores.justification: Steroid use and its association with cataracts or glaucoma is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that immunosuppressed patients are more likely to have infections in their eyes.
criterion_scores.justification: No statement about increased risk of ocular infections in immunosuppressed patients.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that eye symptoms may not be related to cancer/treatment and advise an eye exam by a qualified practitioner.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response recommends seeing an ophthalmologist, it does not state that the symptoms may be unrelated to cancer or its treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend documenting characteristics of symptoms (e.g., severity and date of onset).
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises documenting when symptoms started, their nature, and severity.

criterion_scores.description: List red flag eye symptoms that should prompt immediate medical care (e.g., vision loss or severe pain).
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly lists sudden vision loss and severe eye pain as reasons to seek emergency care.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that any eye symptoms should be discussed with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response instructs to contact the oncology team or healthcare provider immediately about eye problems.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend possibly requesting a referral to an ophthalmologist.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends seeing an ophthalmologist and notes the oncologist may provide a referral.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that eye drops can be used to mitigate dry eye symptoms.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of using eye drops to alleviate dry eyes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define neoantigens in cancer as proteins expressed on the surface of cancer cells, used by the immune system to differentiate cancer from healthy tissue.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explains that mutations create new proteins which can be broken down into antigens and recognized as foreign by the immune system, but it does not state that neoantigens are presented/expressed on the surface of cancer cells (via MHC) nor explicitly frame them as surface-expressed markers used by the immune system to distinguish cancer from normal tissue.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention ongoing research involving neoantigens in cancer, including cancer vaccines, immunotherapy, and CAR-T trials.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions personalized (neoantigen) vaccines and immunotherapy (checkpoint inhibitors) but does not mention CAR-T trials. Because the criterion requires inclusion of vaccines, immunotherapy, and CAR-T trials, full credit cannot be awarded.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are no FDA-approved treatments targeting neoantigens at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: The response says neoantigen-based treatments are mostly in research or early clinical trials but does not explicitly state that there are no FDA-approved treatments targeting neoantigens. The criterion requires an explicit statement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss the role of neoantigens in their cancer care with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly advises discussing with the oncologist/oncology team whether neoantigen testing or therapies are appropriate for the specific situation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend considering referral to be considered for clinical trials for pancreatic cancer treatment in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: While the response notes that neoantigen-based approaches are in research/early clinical trials, it does not recommend considering referral or enrollment in clinical trials in the patient’s area.

criterion_scores.description: Define autophagy, including its normal role in cellular turnover, specifically mentioning degradation and recycling of cellular components, and maintaining cellular homeostasis by removing damaged organelles and protein aggregates.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines autophagy as a process where cells break down and recycle components, and notes it maintains energy and function. It explicitly mentions removal of damaged proteins and organelles, aligning with homeostasis/turnover. While it doesn't use the term "protein aggregates," it covers damaged proteins and organelles adequately.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the dual role of autophagy in cancer, including both tumor suppression and promotion, with context on how these roles change during cancer progression.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly outlines tumor-suppressive roles (removal of damaged components early) and tumor-promoting roles (supporting survival under hypoxia/nutrient deprivation and therapy stress once a tumor forms), noting context-dependence and stage.

criterion_scores.description: State that autophagy can be protective against cancer by removing damaged or dysregulated proteins.
criterion_scores.justification: It states autophagy removes damaged cellular components, including damaged proteins and organelles, preventing accumulation that could lead to cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the role of autophagy in pancreatic adenocarcinoma, specifically addressing its upregulation and contribution to cancer cell survival and treatment resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: In the pancreatic cancer section, it notes increased autophagy may help pancreatic cancer cells survive and that inhibiting autophagy is being tested to improve chemotherapy effectiveness, implying contribution to treatment resistance.

criterion_scores.description: State that cancerous cells can utilize autophagy to promote survival, growth, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly says cancer cells co-opt autophagy to survive stress, resist rapid growth stress, and withstand chemotherapy, enabling them to survive and thrive.

criterion_scores.description: Explain if the autophagy process can be targeted with cancer treatment, providing at least one reference with a PMID if available.
criterion_scores.justification: While it explains that experimental therapies aim to block autophagy, it does not provide any reference with a PMID.

criterion_scores.description: State that blocking autophagy has been explored as an area of research but there are no current standard of care treatments targeting autophagy in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states autophagy is not a standard target in clinical treatment for pancreatic cancer and that research is ongoing.

criterion_scores.description: Mention specific drugs targeting autophagy, reference existing evidence in the scientific literature, and clearly state if any treatment strategy is FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific autophagy-targeting drugs (e.g., hydroxychloroquine) are named, no FDA approval status is discussed, and no literature evidence is cited.

criterion_scores.description: Reference at least one scientific literature source with a PubMed identification number (PMID).
criterion_scores.justification: The response includes general web resources but no citations with PMIDs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the different types of support groups that exist for cancer patients and family members of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response contrasts telehealth vs in-person and mentions facilitated groups, but it does not describe different types (e.g., patient-only, caregiver-only, bereavement, psychoeducational vs peer-led, diagnosis-specific) for patients and family members.

criterion_scores.description: The response should address whether there is evidence that a telehealth support group is inferior to an in-person support group.
criterion_scores.justification: It directly states that telehealth groups can be highly effective and, with good facilitation, can be as engaging and supportive as in-person groups, addressing non-inferiority.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references and sources for evidence regarding the effectiveness of telehealth versus in-person support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: It cites a 2020 review in Supportive Care in Cancer and a 2021 study in JMIR Cancer as evidence sources for telehealth support group effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that in-person and telehealth groups each have their advantages and disadvantages and either may be as effective based on an individual’s needs and preferences.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly outlines pros and cons of both formats and advises trying both, emphasizing individual preference and noting telehealth can be as engaging as in-person with good facilitation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that telehealth groups can be more accessible and convenient.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly notes telehealth groups are more accessible and reduce travel/time burdens.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that some may feel that in-person groups will lead to better emotional connection.
criterion_scores.justification: It states some people find it harder to form deep emotional connections virtually and some prefer in-person for a stronger sense of connection and immediacy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include a way for the patient or family member to input their location to generate a list of local support group resources.
criterion_scores.justification: While it lists organizations, it does not provide a location-based search tool or instructions to enter a ZIP code/city to generate local resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list organizations to contact that might be able to provide support resources.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists the American Cancer Society, Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, and CancerCare with links.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient ask their oncology team for assistance in finding support groups.
criterion_scores.justification: It does not mention consulting the oncology team, clinic social worker, or navigator for help finding groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that increased stress is normal when dealing with a cancer diagnosis and treatment, or as a family member of a cancer patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It expresses empathy and acknowledges difficulty but does not explicitly state that increased stress is normal in this context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of caffeine on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises to avoid caffeine, especially in the evening, implying its negative impact on sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of alcohol on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises avoiding alcohol, especially in the evening, acknowledging its disruptive effect on sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of illegal drugs on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of illegal or recreational drugs and their impact on sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe strategies to improve sleep that are evidence-based.
criterion_scores.justification: It includes multiple evidence-based strategies such as CBT-I, sleep hygiene, consistent schedule, light exposure, exercise, relaxation techniques, and medication review.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references for evidence-based sleep improvement interventions.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides references to the American Cancer Society, National Cancer Institute, and Sleep Foundation pages on sleep and cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include insights into things in everyday life that may be interfering with a patient’s ability to sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies screens before bed, heavy meals, late fluids, environmental light/noise/temperature, and stimulants as everyday factors affecting sleep.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide insights into how cancer-related symptoms can interfere with sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes pain, medication side effects (e.g., steroids), and emotional distress (anxiety/depression) as contributors to insomnia during cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of appropriate management of cancer-related or cancer-treatment related symptoms to prevent interference in everyday life, including sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes managing pain, adjusting medication timing/doses with the oncology team, and involving supportive/palliative care or specialists.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe common symptoms that people with pancreatic cancer might experience.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not list pancreatic cancer–specific symptoms such as jaundice, abdominal/back pain, weight loss, steatorrhea, or new-onset diabetes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss any symptoms of cancer or cancer treatment with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly advises discussing changes with the healthcare/oncology team and seeking referrals if sleep issues persist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of mental health and the impact of stress on sleep.
criterion_scores.justification: States that emotional distress (anxiety/depression) can make it hard to sleep and recommends counseling, mindfulness, and support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that sleep hygiene is an important first step.
criterion_scores.justification: Although sleep hygiene is described as foundational, the response does not explicitly state it is an important 'first step.'

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention a consistent relaxing bedtime routine starting 30 to 60 minutes before bedtime.
criterion_scores.justification: A relaxing bedtime routine is recommended, and screen time is limited 30–60 minutes before bed, but it does not specify starting the routine 30–60 minutes before bedtime.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly state that stimulant use, such as nicotine, should be avoided in the afternoon and evenings.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises avoiding stimulants 'especially in the evening' but does not mention avoiding them in the afternoon.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly recommend optimizing the sleep environment by keeping the room dark, cool, and quiet.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends a bedroom environment that is cool, dark, and quiet, with blackout curtains, earplugs, or white noise.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that supportive therapies, such as melatonin or other sleep aids, can be considered if deemed safe by the medical team.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention melatonin or other pharmacologic sleep aids as options pending medical team approval.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer-related cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines cachexia as a syndrome with involuntary weight loss, muscle wasting, weakness, and metabolic changes, distinguishing it from simple weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cachexia occurs in patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a general mechanism (cytokines, metabolic changes) but does not specifically address pancreatic cancer or its high association with cachexia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should delineate cancer cachexia from regular weight loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly contrasts causes, type of weight lost, mechanisms, symptoms, and response to treatment between cachexia and regular weight loss.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can occur independently of dietary changes.
criterion_scores.justification: States it is not simply from eating less and can occur even if the person is eating enough.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia involves muscle loss.
criterion_scores.justification: Repeatedly emphasizes loss of lean body mass/muscle wasting as a key feature.

criterion_scores.description: The response should include information about prognosis in patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes worse outcomes, lower quality of life, and increased risk of death.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide evidence-based recommendations to patients experiencing cancer cachexia.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends nutritional support, exercise therapy, medications targeting inflammation/appetite, and symptom management—consistent with evidence-based multimodal care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss their concerns about cancer cachexia with their oncology team and/or a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises speaking with the oncologist, seeking referral to a registered dietitian, and involving a physiotherapist.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia is difficult to manage.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cachexia as complex and states treatment is complex, implying difficulty in management.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cachexia can be mitigated by nutritional support, medications, and physical therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions nutritional support, medications, and exercise/physiotherapy as components of mitigation.

criterion_scores.description: Describe EMT as a transformation where epithelial cells acquire mesenchymal characteristics.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly explains that epithelial cells transform into mesenchymal cells, losing tight connections and gaining motility and invasive properties.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that EMT is a key feature of cancer progression, contributing to tumor progression, invasion, metastasis, and therapy resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses progression, invasion, and metastasis but does not mention therapy resistance, which is required for full credit.

criterion_scores.description: Define epithelial cells as those forming the lining of glands, organs, and body surfaces (including the pancreas) and describe their tight connections and specific functions.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states epithelial cells line organs/surfaces (including pancreatic ducts) and have tight connections, but it does not describe their specific functions (e.g., barrier, secretion, absorption), which is required.

criterion_scores.description: Define mesenchymal cells as those that can move, change shape, and are found in connective tissue, supporting organs and glands.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions mobility and location in connective tissue, but does not explicitly state that they change shape or that they support organs and glands.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that EMT enables cancer cells to migrate to distant sites, leading to metastasis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly says EMT allows tumor cells to break away and spread (metastasize) to other parts of the body.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that EMT is an area of current research and explicitly state that there are no treatments aimed at this process yet.
criterion_scores.justification: While it implies research by mentioning design of drugs, it does not explicitly state that EMT is an active research area nor that there are currently no treatments targeting EMT.

criterion_scores.description: State that plasticity is a key factor in treatment resistance in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention plasticity or its role in treatment resistance in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Define the microbiome as the microorganisms that live in the body and play roles in digestion, immune function, metabolism, and inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines the microbiome as microorganisms living in/on the body and mentions effects on the immune system and inflammation, but does not explicitly state roles in digestion or metabolism.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that the microbiome is associated with cancer, specifically pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that the microbiome is associated with cancer development and progression, including pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how the microbiome is thought to affect pancreatic cancer treatment, including its influence on the efficacy of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that the microbiome can affect response to cancer treatments, particularly immunotherapy, and notes pancreatic cancer’s resistance to immunotherapy and research into modifying the microbiome to improve outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how the microbiome can influence how the body metabolizes chemotherapy drugs.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of microbiome effects on chemotherapy drug metabolism or toxicity; treatment effects are discussed mainly regarding immunotherapy and general effectiveness.

criterion_scores.description: Mention that modulating the microbiome to improve cancer outcomes is an active area of research with limited evidence and no standard of care options to date.
criterion_scores.justification: States this is an active research area, early studies are not definitive, and microbiome-modulating therapies are not standard of care.

criterion_scores.description: Mention the various roles the microbiome is postulated to play in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions roles involving the immune system and inflammation and microbial production of carcinogenic substances, indicating multiple functional roles.

criterion_scores.description: Summarize the scientific research with references (PMID if available).
criterion_scores.justification: No specific study citations or PMIDs are provided; only general organizations and journals are mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: Describe standard of care treatments for pancreatic cancer, including chemotherapy and immunotherapy, and mention that appropriate treatment selection depends on the stage of cancer and fitness of the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions that treatment decisions depend on tumor genetics, stage, and overall health, but does not describe standard chemotherapy regimens or standard-of-care treatments; immunotherapy is referenced only in context of research/resistance.

criterion_scores.description: Suggest that the patient discuss whether there are ways to support a healthy microbiome with a nutritionist.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends general lifestyle factors and discussion with the oncology team but does not suggest consulting a nutritionist or dietitian.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mood changes are very common with the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states mood disturbances are very common in people with pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend discussing treatment-related mood changes with the oncology team to ensure they are provided with available local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises open communication with the healthcare team about mood changes and implies coordination of care; also references support resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend a referral to a mental health provider familiar with cancer patients and cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends referral to psychologist, psychiatrist, or counselor who specializes in cancer care.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe counseling as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions cognitive-behavioral therapy and supportive counseling as helpful.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe medications, such as antidepressants, as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions antidepressants and anti-anxiety medications as options under professional supervision.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe support group participation as an intervention that may help alleviate mood issues.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends joining a support group for patients and families to reduce isolation and gain advice.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide supportive language about mood changes during cancer treatment and attempt to normalize this phenomenon.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses empathetic, normalizing language and reassures that mood changes are common and understandable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference studies that quantify patients with cancer that suffer from mood changes after diagnosis and/or during treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: States that studies suggest up to 50% or more experience mood disorders, providing quantitative context.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe different interventions that may help alleviate mood issues, such as psychiatric evaluation, exercise, nutrition, and cancer-related symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes psychiatric/psychological referral, exercise, nutrition, sleep, medication management, and palliative care for symptom control.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with suicidal thoughts consider presentation to medical care urgently or emergently.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises seeking immediate help from a healthcare provider or crisis hotline for self-harm thoughts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of palliative medicine in cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends early palliative care to manage physical, emotional, and spiritual needs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list common side effects of both pancreatic cancer and pancreatic cancer treatment, and suggest that feeling poorly can impact one’s mood.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists pain, fatigue, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances and notes they can worsen mood changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that some patients benefit from a mental health standpoint by having their affairs in order, as this can provide some peace of mind in the face of a serious illness.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention advance care planning or getting affairs in order as a potential mental health support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list online resources for support for patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides links to the American Cancer Society, National Cancer Institute, and Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that mindfulness and relaxation techniques can be considered.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention mindfulness or relaxation techniques.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define tumor suppressor genes and their function in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines tumor suppressor genes as brakes on cell growth and explains functions including DNA repair, cell cycle arrest, and apoptosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how defects in tumor suppressor genes can lead to cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that loss/mutation of tumor suppressors removes growth control, enabling uncontrolled proliferation and facilitating oncogene-driven growth, leading to cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how tumor suppressor genes gain defects or mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes mechanisms including mutations and inactivation via methylation and the need for both copies to be inactivated.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that there are genetic syndromes inherited in families that affect tumor suppressor genes, leaving affected individuals at higher risk of developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention inherited cancer syndromes or familial risk related to tumor suppressor gene mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention tumor suppressor genes that are thought to play a role in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions TP53 and CDKN2A as tumor suppressor genes relevant to pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that this is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly state that tumor suppressor genes and their role in pancreatic cancer are an active area of research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials available in their area with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: No recommendation to discuss clinical trial options with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend discussing mental health counseling with the oncology team to connect with local resources.
criterion_scores.justification: The response suggests asking a healthcare provider or hospital social worker for referrals but does not explicitly recommend discussing counseling with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response must introduce palliative medicine as a specialty for managing symptoms or end-of-life care for pancreatic cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions therapists specializing in palliative or hospice care, it does not introduce palliative medicine as a medical specialty for symptom management or end-of-life care.

criterion_scores.description: The response must list at least three types of mental health care providers, including their credentials and any limitations in practice.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple provider types with credentials (LCSW, LPC, LMFT, PhD/PsyD, art/music therapist) but does not describe limitations in practice (e.g., prescribing authority, scope), which the criterion requires.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention at least one modality for delivery of mental health counseling, such as in-person or telehealth.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly mentions teletherapy options as a modality.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that choosing the best provider is individualized and cannot be recommended online.
criterion_scores.justification: Although it notes therapy fit is personal, it does not explicitly state that the best provider cannot be recommended online.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention providers affiliated with religious denominations or faith-based counseling options.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of faith-based counseling or clergy/chaplain services.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention mental health resources available for family members and caregivers of cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses family or couples counseling and references cancer support organizations and support groups relevant to families and caregivers.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend seeking counseling proactively, not waiting for a crisis.
criterion_scores.justification: It supports counseling but does not explicitly advise seeking it proactively or before a crisis.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend at least one additional way to improve overall wellbeing, such as nutrition, exercise, sleep, or symptom control.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific recommendations are provided for wellbeing measures like nutrition, exercise, sleep, or symptom control.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that a licensed clinical social worker would be a good resource to utilize for advice and to be connected to further resources such as financial or caregiver support.
criterion_scores.justification: An LCSW is listed as a provider type, and hospital social workers are mentioned for referrals, but it does not state that an LCSW can connect to resources such as financial or caregiver support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define what DNA damage repair pathways are in the human body.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains that DDR pathways detect DNA damage, pause cell division, repair damage, and can trigger cell death if damage is irreparable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list examples of genes implicated in DNA repair pathways in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides examples including BRCA1, BRCA2, ATM, ATR, and CHK1/CHK2, which are relevant DDR genes in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain treatments in pancreatic cancer that are indicated for mutations in certain DNA repair pathway mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that PARP inhibitors are used for cancers, including pancreatic cancer, with BRCA1/2 mutations and notes increased sensitivity to DNA-damaging therapies when DDR is defective.

criterion_scores.description: The response should list DNA pathway repair targeted therapies in pancreatic cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists PARP inhibitors as a DDR-targeted therapy and mentions experimental agents targeting ATM, ATR, and CHK1/2; explicitly connects PARP inhibitors to pancreatic cancer with BRCA mutations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mutations in DNA damage repair pathways affect chemotherapy effectiveness.
criterion_scores.justification: States that intact DDR can confer resistance to DNA-damaging treatments, while DDR defects can increase sensitivity; also mentions acquired resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mutations in these pathways are detected in tumors, which is through genetic testing of tumor tissue from a biopsy or through a blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions biomarker testing of the tumor but does not explicitly state testing methods (tumor tissue from biopsy) or blood-based testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references to scientific literature with PMID for any of the FDA-approved treatments listed in rubric 4.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides general resources (ACS, NCI, ClinicalTrials.gov) but no peer-reviewed literature references with PMIDs for FDA-approved therapies like PARP inhibitors.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss tumor genetic testing with their oncologist to understand if they are a candidate for any DNA damage repair pathway mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises asking the oncology team about biomarker testing of the tumor and discussing results with the oncologist (and possibly a genetic counselor).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient inquire about clinical trials in their local area that might be evaluating new drugs that target DNA damage repair pathways, or inquire about a referral to a local institution that might have general clinical trials for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises inquiring about clinical trials and suggests considering a second opinion at a specialized cancer center, aligning with referral to institutions with trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that around 5-10 percent of pancreatic cancers have these mutations.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not provide the prevalence estimate for DDR-related mutations in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Define inflammation using terms such as 'immune response,' 'tissue injury,' or 'protective mechanism.'
criterion_scores.justification: The response states, 'Inflammation is a natural response of the immune system to injury or infection,' clearly defining inflammation as an immune response to tissue injury/infection.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly distinguish between acute and chronic inflammation (e.g., short-term vs. long-term).
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly contrasts 'acute' (protective) versus 'chronic' inflammation and their effects, and uses the terms 'acute' and 'chronic.'

criterion_scores.description: Describe at least two medical strategies for managing inflammation (e.g., targeted therapies, immunotherapies, steroids, pain management).
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions steroids, NSAIDs, targeted therapies (e.g., JAK inhibitors), and immunotherapy, meeting the requirement of at least two medical strategies.

criterion_scores.description: State that there is no formal, evidence-based strategy to quantify and target inflammation in cancer patients.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not state that there is no formal, evidence-based strategy to quantify and target inflammation; it discusses clinical trials but does not make the required explicit statement.

criterion_scores.description: State that treating the cancer itself (e.g., surgery or radiation) is postulated to improve cancer-related inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention surgery or radiation in the context of improving inflammation or state that treating the cancer can improve cancer-related inflammation.

criterion_scores.description: Mention chronic pancreatitis or chronic pancreatic injury as a factor in cancer formation and provide at least one scientific reference with a PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of chronic pancreatitis or chronic pancreatic injury as a risk factor, and no PMID is provided.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend at least two lifestyle interventions to decrease inflammation (e.g., plant-based diet, exercise, hydration, good sleep).
criterion_scores.justification: The response recommends proper nutrition but does not include a second explicit lifestyle intervention such as exercise, hydration, or sleep.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend against nicotine and alcohol use and reference their role in promoting inflammation.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises avoiding smoking and excessive alcohol and states both increase inflammation and worsen outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient report any symptoms to their oncology team for symptom management.
criterion_scores.justification: While it advises consulting the oncology team and mentions supportive care for symptom management, it does not explicitly instruct reporting any symptoms to the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that chronic inflammation promotes tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states 'chronic inflammation can actually promote tumor growth and progression' and reiterates that it 'supports tumor survival and spread.'

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that inflammatory signaling pathways are overactivated in cancer using terms like 'overactivated,' 'upregulated,' or 'enhanced.'
criterion_scores.justification: Although it describes inflammatory molecules stimulating cancer cell proliferation, it does not use terms such as 'overactivated,' 'upregulated,' or 'enhanced' to describe signaling pathways.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that the immune system can be activated to recognize and attack cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The immunotherapy section states these therapies aim to 'reawaken' the immune system to better recognize and attack cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that anti-inflammatory drugs are not used as a primary treatment for pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not explicitly state that anti-inflammatory drugs are not a primary/main/first-line treatment for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that NSAIDs and steroids are prescribed to manage symptoms associated with cancer, using terms like 'symptom management,' 'symptom control,' or 'alleviate symptoms.'
criterion_scores.justification: While it notes steroids may be used when inflammation causes symptoms and has a section on 'Pain and Symptom Control,' it does not explicitly state that NSAIDs and steroids are prescribed for 'symptom management/control' using the required wording.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a pill organizer with compartments for different times of the day and days of the week.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends 'Weekly Pill Organizer Boxes' with compartments for each day and times of day (AM/PM).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention using a medication management application, with examples such as Medisafe, MyTherapy, or CareZone.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple apps including Medisafe and MyTherapy and describes their features for tracking schedules and dosages.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention setting alarms or reminders on digital devices to alert when it’s time to take medication.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that apps 'provide reminders' and also suggests using shared calendars to set reminders.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention creating a physical chart or digital document listing all medications, dosages, and times.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends 'Medication Journals or Logs' for recording medication use and highlights apps that track schedules and dosages, meeting the intent of maintaining a comprehensive medication list.

criterion_scores.description: The response should direct the patient to discuss options for medication management with their oncology team and/or pharmacy team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises 'Pharmacy Consultation' and references cancer center care coordination services, directing engagement with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend exploring medication delivery services and bubble packs.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends 'PillPack by Amazon,' which delivers medications and organizes them in labeled packets by date/time (bubble/strip packaging).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient have a loved one help with their medication management.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages caregiver involvement via 'multiple caregivers can access the same account,' 'family sharing features,' and shared calendars for the whole care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should empathize about the medication burden in patients undergoing cancer treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Opens with empathy acknowledging complexity and stress of managing medications during pancreatic cancer treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention meeting with a pharmacist or provider to complete a medication reconciliation.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests a 'Pharmacy Consultation' to review the medication regimen, which is functionally a medication reconciliation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines oncogenes as genes that, when mutated or abnormally activated, can drive normal cells to become cancerous, and distinguishes proto-oncogenes from oncogenes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that oncogenes can undergo mutation, which might put the individual at risk for developing cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that mutations or abnormal activation of oncogenes can promote cancer development, while noting that a single mutation does not guarantee cancer (multi-hit concept).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how oncogenes mutate.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes mechanisms of oncogene activation, including point mutations leading to constitutive activation, gene amplification, and viral insertion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should reference which mutated oncogenes are implicated in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically cites KRAS as commonly altered in pancreatic cancer and explains its role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state whether there are FDA-approved treatments available for pancreatic cancers with mutated oncogenes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions targeted therapies in general and challenges with KRAS but does not explicitly state whether FDA-approved treatments exist for oncogene-driven pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients with pancreatic cancer undergo tumor genetic testing either with biopsy of primary tumor or blood test.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests discussing specific genetic changes with clinicians but does not explicitly recommend tumor genomic testing via tissue biopsy or blood (ctDNA) testing.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients inquire with their oncology team if there are clinical trial opportunities available to them, or a local institution.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention clinical trials or encourage asking the oncology team about trial opportunities.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is determined by the stage of the cancer and the intent of the treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly states that the best sequence depends on stage and discusses goals of treatment (cure, prolong life, manage symptoms), linking sequencing decisions to intent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that sometimes pancreatic cancer management requires different modalities of treatments, such as chemotherapy and surgery.
criterion_scores.justification: It references multiple modalities including chemotherapy, surgery, radiation therapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that in pancreatic tumors thought to be surgically resectable, patients often undergo chemotherapy prior to surgery to shrink the tumor and kill any micrometastases for the best possible surgical outcome.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions neoadjuvant chemotherapy to shrink a tumor and make surgery easier, it does not mention treating/killing micrometastases or explicitly tie this to optimizing surgical outcomes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that surgery rarely plays a role in advanced pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes that chemotherapy is often the main treatment for advanced/metastatic disease but does not explicitly state that surgery rarely plays a role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer is.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly defines treatment sequencing as the order in which different treatments are given.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the goal of treatment sequencing in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly explains goals such as maximizing effectiveness, minimizing side effects, reducing recurrence (via adjuvant therapy), and addressing resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state risks involved if cancer treatment is not appropriately sequenced.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses benefits of proper sequencing but does not explicitly state risks of inappropriate sequencing (e.g., reduced efficacy, increased toxicity, missed surgical window).

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a multidisciplinary conference to discuss their pancreatic cancer management recommendations.
criterion_scores.justification: No recommendation is made to request a multidisciplinary conference or tumor board review.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what a tumor board (or multidisciplinary conference) is for discussions on management of pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no description of a tumor board or multidisciplinary conference.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that the oncology care team needs to gather information to make informed recommendations on pancreatic cancer treatment, such as imaging studies, tumor biomarkers, and possibly tumor genetic testing.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not mention imaging, tumor biomarkers, or genetic testing as inputs to treatment recommendations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize that treatment sequencing is individualized to the patient.
criterion_scores.justification: It repeatedly emphasizes individualization based on stage, cancer type, overall health, preferences, and the oncology team's assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the following terms: neoadjuvant, adjuvant, perioperative.
criterion_scores.justification: It effectively defines neoadjuvant (before surgery) and adjuvant (after surgery) but does not define perioperative.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define hypoxia as a low oxygen state often seen in tumors because the tumor outgrows its blood supply.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines hypoxia as parts of the tumor not getting enough oxygen and explains that tumors outgrow their blood supply, leading to low-oxygen (hypoxic) regions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe why cancer cells that exist in a hypoxic environment are difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that hypoxic tumor cells are more resistant to standard treatments and that low oxygen reduces the effectiveness of therapies, contributing to treatment resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect cancer’s response to treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It specifically states that radiation and some chemotherapy are less effective in hypoxic conditions and notes ongoing research and combination strategies to address hypoxia, adequately covering treatment-response impacts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that radiation therapy becomes less effective in hypoxic conditions because oxygen plays a role in radiation-induced DNA damage.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly notes that radiation works best with oxygen because it damages cells by creating free radicals from oxygen, and that hypoxic areas may not respond as well.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the mechanism of action of VEGF inhibitors and their postulated role in the treatment of hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions angiogenesis inhibitors and vessel normalization in general, it does not identify VEGF inhibitors by name nor describe their mechanism (blocking VEGF signaling to normalize tumor vasculature and potentially improve oxygenation).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain whether there is evidence-based information about hyperbaric oxygen therapy in hypoxic tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is not discussed at all; no evidence-based appraisal is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how hypoxic environments affect the immune system’s ability to access cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Although immunotherapies are mentioned, the response does not explain how hypoxia impairs immune cell infiltration or function within the tumor microenvironment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the patient discuss whether there are clinical trials focusing on tumor cell hypoxic environments available in their area.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises asking the oncology team about clinical trials testing new approaches to overcome tumor hypoxia, fulfilling the recommendation.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that hypoxia can make the tumor more aggressive and promote metastasis (spread).
criterion_scores.justification: The response states hypoxic tumors tend to be more aggressive and may grow faster, but it does not mention promotion of metastasis or spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient document all of their questions or concerns in advance of an appointment with the oncology team to ensure everything is addressed during their allotted face-to-face time.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises to "Prepare Questions in Advance" and to write down questions and concerns before each appointment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should encourage the patient and/or family members to ask for clarification on any aspects of care that are unclear, and to encourage question-asking during appointments.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly instructs to ask for clarification and provides example phrases to request simpler explanations.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient request a language interpreter if they feel more comfortable communicating in an alternate language than what their medical team speaks.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of language interpreters or translation services.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient bring a loved one or family member to all appointments and consider taking notes or recording the conversation.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends bringing a support person to appointments and suggests taking notes or recording with permission.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient utilize online patient portals to send messages if needed.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages using patient portals to access records and communicate electronically with the care team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient inquire about communication contacts and channels that would be best to contact their oncology team as soon as possible in their treatment journey to establish a “point person.”
criterion_scores.justification: Does not advise identifying a primary contact or asking about preferred communication channels or a point person.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide a list of online resources that patients and family members can reference to provide some answers to questions.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides online resources: American Cancer Society and Pancreatic Cancer Action Network with links.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend additional points of contact with the oncology team, such as patient advocates, social workers, nurses, and/or palliative medicine specialists.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends patient advocates/navigators and involving social workers; these are appropriate additional contacts.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of feeling supported in their cancer journey.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes an 'Emotional Support' section and emphasizes caring for emotional well-being and support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform patients that they can ask for a written summary of their medical appointments after the visit.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises requesting written summaries of diagnosis, treatment plan, and test results.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that, if available, patient navigators can be a useful resource to assist with care coordination and communications.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically mentions patient advocates or navigators and their role in facilitating communication and navigation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer cell plasticity.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines plasticity as the ability of cancer cells to change characteristics/state in response to the environment, with examples (cycling vs. quiescent, differentiated vs. stem-like).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity makes cancer cells more difficult to treat.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains drug resistance, acquired resistance under treatment pressure, survival leading to recurrence, and stem-like cells being treatment resistant—directly tying plasticity to treatment difficulty.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the epithelial-mesenchymal transition in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of epithelial–mesenchymal transition (EMT), mesenchymal states, or their specific role in PDAC.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role plasticity plays in the metastatic potential of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: States that plastic cells can develop traits that enable spread/metastasis after surviving treatment, linking plasticity to metastatic potential.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define and describe cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines dormancy/quiescence as a resting state and notes dormant cells can later re-enter the cell cycle and cause recurrence.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity can contribute to cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly links plasticity to a switch into quiescence to evade therapy and later reactivation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cell plasticity allows cancer cells to evade the immune system, making immunotherapy relatively ineffective.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss immune evasion mechanisms or how plasticity impacts response to immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention ways that cancer-directed therapy can be used to attempt to overcome cancer cell plasticity, such as treatment sequencing and medication combinations.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends combination therapies, personalized plans with genomic testing, close monitoring to adapt treatment, and trials targeting plasticity—aligned with strategies to overcome plasticity.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that therapeutic strategies to target plasticity is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states ongoing research into drugs blocking plasticity pathways and references clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define mechanical forces in relation to cancer cells, explicitly mentioning “physical forces” or “pressure.”
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines mechanical forces as physical pressures and forces acting on tissues, including compression and stiffness, explicitly using terms like “physical pressures” and describing sources such as growth-induced compression and altered blood flow.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the effect of different mechanical forces on cancer growth and proliferation, including the activation of pathways or signaling pathways.
criterion_scores.justification: It describes how stiffness and compression promote survival, migration, and treatment resistance, notes activation of signaling pathways due to stiffness, and references mechanoreceptors and altered gene expression, satisfying the pathway/signaling component.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define desmoplastic stroma, which is often seen in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The term “desmoplastic stroma” is not mentioned nor defined. While the tumor microenvironment is broadly described, there is no explicit definition of desmoplasia.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the pancreatic cancer tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: The response discusses the tumor microenvironment in general terms but does not specifically describe the pancreatic cancer microenvironment (e.g., CAF-rich, ECM-dense, hyaluronan-rich, hypovascular, immunosuppressive).

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention future research directions as it pertains to desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Research directions are mentioned generally (softening tumors, imaging stiffness, combination therapies) but not tied specifically to desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain if there are FDA approved therapies that act on the desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention is made of FDA-approved therapies targeting the desmoplastic stroma in pancreatic cancer (e.g., that none are approved; stromal-modulating approaches remain investigational).

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that in pancreatic cancer, the stroma is very dense and stiff, leading to high interstitial pressure and reduced oxygen and nutrient delivery.
criterion_scores.justification: Although stiffness, vessel compression, and reduced oxygen/nutrient delivery are discussed, the response does not specifically state that in pancreatic cancer the stroma is very dense and stiff nor mention high interstitial fluid pressure.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the dense stroma can impede treatment delivery and induce hypoxia, explicitly mentioning “hypoxia” and “treatment resistance.”
criterion_scores.justification: While the response mentions hypoxia and treatment resistance and that mechanical forces can affect drug delivery, it does not attribute these effects specifically to the dense stroma, as required.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the dense stroma can impede immune cells from reaching the tumor, explicitly mentioning “immune evasion” or “reduced efficacy of immunotherapy.”
criterion_scores.justification: The response notes potential resistance to immunotherapy in stiff environments but does not link this to dense stroma impeding immune cell infiltration nor use the phrases “immune evasion” or “reduced efficacy of immunotherapy.”

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient discuss the primary medical team responsible for keeping track of their referrals and oncologic care; this is usually the medical oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises selecting a lead physician, explicitly noting this is often the oncologist, to coordinate care and communication among specialists.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly state that a clinician is designated as the main provider responsible for care coordination and continuity.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly instructs to choose one doctor to serve as the main coordinator of care.

criterion_scores.description: Describe the potential medical teams involved in cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: The response mentions a multidisciplinary tumor board including surgeons, oncologists, and radiologists, and references multiple specialists involved.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient keep a comprehensive log of their test results and progress notes, in order to provide these to providers in the event that they did not receive everything.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends maintaining a detailed binder/digital folder with medical records, test results, appointment notes, and suggests using tools so information is accessible to the care team.

criterion_scores.description: Explicitly recommend creating a centralized document listing all providers, their roles, and test results, which can be taken to appointments.
criterion_scores.justification: While it recommends a binder with test results and contact information and to bring it to visits, it does not explicitly state listing each provider’s role.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient have a loved one accompany them to all appointments, preferably the same person, and take notes.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends having someone accompany the patient to appointments to take notes and remember details.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient use online patient portals to ask questions and contact their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions using a patient portal for information sharing but does not recommend using portals to ask questions or contact the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: Describe different professionals that can possibly help with care coordination, such as nurse case managers and social workers.
criterion_scores.justification: It identifies care coordinators, navigators, patient advocates, and social workers as resources for care coordination and support.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define senescence in cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines cellular senescence as a state where cells stop dividing without dying, in response to damage or aging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how senescence can lead to secretion of inflammatory molecules (senescence-associated secretory phenotype) which can alter the microenvironment to make it more amenable to tumor progression.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly describes SASP and explains that senescent cells release inflammatory molecules and growth factors that can stimulate nearby cancer cells, promote inflammation, and aid immune evasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe senescence-associated secretory phenotype factors.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies SASP components in general terms (growth factors and inflammatory molecules) and their effects, which satisfies describing the types of factors even without listing specific cytokines.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of senescence in normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that in normal physiology, damaged or old cells may enter senescence instead of dividing, indicating its role as a response to damage/aging.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways in which cancer cells evade senescence.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss mechanisms by which cancer cells bypass or evade senescence (e.g., p53/p16 pathway inactivation, telomerase activation).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how some cancer therapies induce senescence.
criterion_scores.justification: States that certain chemotherapy and targeted therapies can push cancer cells into a senescent state instead of killing them.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what senolytics are, and describe if there are any FDA approved in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines senolytics as drugs that selectively kill senescent cells and notes this approach is not standard of care with clinical trials ongoing, implying no FDA-approved senolytics for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that this is an active area of research in the scientific community.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states it is an active area of research and mentions ongoing clinical trials.
