criterion_scores.description: The response should state that senescence is caused by cellular stressors such as DNA damage or activation of tumor suppressor genes.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions DNA damage and treatment stress as triggers for senescence, satisfying the criterion via the example of DNA damage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that senescence can be a positive factor as it stops tumor growth.
criterion_scores.justification: States that tumor-suppressive senescence stops cell division, preventing growth into new cancer cells, which is beneficial.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define exosomes as vesicles that cells can release into their surroundings.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines exosomes as tiny membrane-bound vesicles released by almost all cell types.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what exosomes contain, such as proteins, lipids, and RNA.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists proteins, lipids, and nucleic acids (including microRNAs) as exosomal cargo.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of exosomes in cancer cells, including cell-cell communication.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes exosomes as intercellular messengers and explains cancer cell–to–cell communication effects.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of exosomes in tumor promotion.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains how exosomes promote angiogenesis, alter stromal behavior, and support tumor growth.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of exosomes in immune evasion.
criterion_scores.justification: States that tumor exosomes suppress immune activity and help tumors evade detection.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of exosomes in drug resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention exosome-mediated drug resistance mechanisms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the emerging or experimental role of exosomes as tumor biomarkers.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies exosomes as potential biomarkers detectable in blood/fluids and notes active research.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how exosomes travel in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Indicates long-distance communication and detectability in blood/other bodily fluids, implying circulation-based transport.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how exosomes are thought to facilitate metastases in cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes preparation of distant sites (pre-metastatic niche) making them more receptive to tumor spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe if there are any FDA approved treatments that are associated with cancer exosomes.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes lack of routine clinical use but does not explicitly address FDA-approved treatments.

criterion_scores.description: Define advance directive and living will, and recommend completion/update near end of life
criterion_scores.justification: Explains these documents as expressing preferences for treatment (resuscitation, life support, pain management) and recommends completing them 'as soon as possible.'

criterion_scores.description: Recommend a palliative medicine consultation to consider transitioning focus to comfort
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing hospice or palliative care options with the medical team and notes these services focus on comfort and quality of life, indicating a shift from disease-targeted care.

criterion_scores.description: Describe Hospice and include <6 months prognosis eligibility
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions hospice but does not state the Medicare-standard eligibility of an estimated prognosis of six months or less.

criterion_scores.description: Describe categories of tasks approaching end of life for pancreatic cancer
criterion_scores.justification: Covers medical decision-making, financial/legal planning, practical care arrangements, emotional/spiritual support, communication with the medical team, and after-death arrangements.

criterion_scores.description: Define medical durable power of attorney
criterion_scores.justification: Defines healthcare proxy/medical DPOA as appointing someone to make medical decisions if the patient cannot communicate wishes.

criterion_scores.description: Describe steps to elect a medical durable power of attorney
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends appointing someone but does not outline steps (selecting agent, completing state-specific form, witnessing/notarizing, distributing copies).

criterion_scores.description: Define a POLST and recommend completing and displaying at home
criterion_scores.justification: POLST is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: Ensure healthcare teams have a copy of the POLST
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of POLST or distributing it to healthcare teams.

criterion_scores.description: State hospice benefits vary across insurance plans; understand specific benefits
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of insurance variability of hospice benefits.

criterion_scores.description: Include that hospice provides services for patient and for family/caregivers
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions counseling and support groups generally but does not state that hospice specifically provides services/support to family and caregivers.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend electing a financial durable power of attorney
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly recommends a financial power of attorney to manage finances and pay bills if the patient is unable.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend considering and communicating funeral arrangements
criterion_scores.justification: Advises discussing and documenting funeral/burial/cremation preferences and mentions planning memorial/celebration of life.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend planning for religious/spiritual rituals
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages arranging spiritual care so beliefs and rituals are honored.

criterion_scores.description: Describe importance of open communication between patient and decision makers to respect wishes
criterion_scores.justification: Emphasizes maintaining honest, open communication about wishes and changes; also encourages communicating preferences (e.g., funeral) to loved ones.

criterion_scores.description: State end-of-life planning is individualized and should follow the patient's wishes
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights ensuring the loved one's wishes are respected and suggests personalized guidance, reflecting individualized planning centered on patient preferences.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define cancer cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines dormancy as a state where cancer cells are present but not actively dividing (quiescent), potentially undetectable and able to reactivate later.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain how long a cancer cell can remain dormant in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: States duration is variable and unknown, notes evidence of dormancy lasting years to decades in some cancers and mentions typical recurrence timelines, addressing the time dimension.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain why it is advantageous for cancer cells to be able to enter a dormant state.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that dormant cells may evade detection and later reactivate to cause recurrence, implying survival advantage and treatment evasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe scenarios in which a cancer cell may be prompted to enter dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists multiple triggers such as hypoxia/nutrient deprivation, immune surveillance, genetic changes slowing division, and suppressive signals from surrounding cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe what is known about cancer cell dormancy in pancreatic cancer, preferably with references to the scientific literature with PMID.
criterion_scores.justification: States research in pancreatic cancer is limited but provides no pancreatic cancer–specific details or PMIDs; cited resources are general and not pancreas-specific.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that dormancy can occur because of microenvironmental or genetic factors.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions microenvironmental factors (nutrient/oxygen deprivation, surrounding cell signals) and genetic changes leading to slowed division.

criterion_scores.description: The dormant cells will often be less susceptible to chemotherapy than rapidly dividing cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address chemotherapy susceptibility of dormant cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that these dormant cells can lead to disease recurrence after treatments as they can reactivate after a long period of time.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states dormant cells can 'awaken' and grow again, leading to recurrence, potentially after long periods.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that dormancy is an active area of research.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes that researchers are actively studying dormancy and suggests clinical trials, indicating it is an active research area.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define mechanical stress as physical forces and pressures exerted on and within a tumor mass, arising from tumor growth, interactions with surrounding tissues, and the tumor’s microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines mechanical stress as physical forces (solid stress, fluid shear stress, matrix stiffness) within the tumor microenvironment, including pressure from tumor growth compressing vessels and ECM stiffness.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how mechanical stress on tumor cells impacts their ability to grow and metastasize.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains effects on tumor growth/survival and details how mechanical cues promote detachment, invasion, and metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the relationship between mechanical stress in tumors and hypoxia.
criterion_scores.justification: States that solid stress compresses blood vessels, limiting oxygen and nutrients and causing hypoxia, which can select for more aggressive cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain that mechanical stress on tumor tissue is implicated in treatment resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes how mechanical stress contributes to drug delivery barriers and can induce resistant/dormant states; mentions impacts on chemo and immunotherapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define the tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines tumors as complex tissues with their own microenvironment and identifies components like stroma and physical forces, conveying the concept adequately.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe sources of mechanical stress in tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists solid stress from growth, fluid shear stress from fluid flow, and matrix stiffness from ECM changes.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform the patient that effects of mechanical stress on tumor tissue are not fully elucidated and are an area of active scientific research.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes active research and ongoing exploration but does not explicitly state that the effects are not fully elucidated.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention the effect of mechanical stress on the tumor in angiogenesis, invasion, metastasis, and promotion of tumor cell survival.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers invasion, metastasis, and survival, but does not explicitly mention angiogenesis.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that pancreatic cancer is characterized by a very dense and stiff stroma, leading to high interstitial pressure and reduced oxygen and nutrient delivery.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions dense stroma and stiffness in PDAC and general vessel compression, but does not explicitly state high interstitial pressure or link PDAC stroma to reduced oxygen/nutrient delivery.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the dense stroma can impede immune cells from reaching the tumor, aiding immune evasion and reducing the efficacy of immunotherapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes mechanical stress impeding immune cell infiltration and mentions immunotherapy resistance in general, but does not attribute this to the dense stroma specifically or explicitly state reduced immunotherapy efficacy due to stromal barriers.

criterion_scores.description: Define tumor organoids as a miniature 3D model of the patient’s tumor grown in a lab from the patient’s own cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines organoids as tiny 3D structures grown in the lab from a small piece of the patient’s tumor, mimicking the original tumor.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how tumor organoids are used for testing cancer medications to determine the most effective one.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains testing different drugs and combinations on a patient’s organoid and using results to predict the most effective treatment.

criterion_scores.description: Explain that the use of tumor organoids is experimental and not available at all cancer centers, and that there are no large randomized clinical trials for tumor organoids.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states usage is limited to specialized/research settings, implying limited availability, but does not state there are no large randomized clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how tumor organoids are grown.
criterion_scores.justification: It outlines the process: obtaining a biopsy/surgical sample, dissociating tissue, growing cells in a supportive 3D gel with nutrients, and maintaining cultures over weeks to months.

criterion_scores.description: Explain how tumor organoids are different than cultured cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Although the response notes organoids preserve structure and genetics, it does not explicitly compare organoids to traditional 2D cultured cell lines or explain the differences.

criterion_scores.description: Describe how tumor organoids are used to tailor treatments to the patient from which they are derived.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly discusses personalized medicine and predicting patient-specific treatment responses using the patient’s own organoids.

criterion_scores.description: Describe advantages of using patient-derived organoids for research.
criterion_scores.justification: Advantages are described, including preservation of tumor structure/genetics, ability to study biology and drug resistance, and testing new therapies.

criterion_scores.description: Describe limitations of using patient-derived organoids for research.
criterion_scores.justification: Limitations specific to research (e.g., lack of full tumor microenvironment, variable success rates, time/cost) are not discussed; only clinical availability is mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient choose a medical decision maker, or medical durable power of attorney, who will make medical decisions for her in the event she is unable to do so herself.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises designating a healthcare proxy/power of attorney for healthcare if the mother is unable to decide, aligning with the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient and her legal next of kin request assistance from social work from their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends involving a hospital social worker, which satisfies advising social work involvement through the care team, even though it does not explicitly say 'from the oncology team.'

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform the patient about the role of palliative medicine in cancer care, who are providers who can help establish a patient’s goals of care and can assist with documentation of this.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention palliative care or its role in goals-of-care discussions or documentation.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient designate a primary family member who can attend appointments and relay information to other family members.
criterion_scores.justification: No suggestion to designate a single primary family point person to attend appointments and relay information.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend the establishment of a meeting schedule, where the primary family member or patient meets with a greater group of family members for regular updates.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions family meetings in general but does not recommend a structured, scheduled update process or regular cadence.

criterion_scores.description: The response must state that the priority should be the patient’s own personal wishes and that she should be as involved in the decision-making process as possible.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states the mother should be included in decisions as much as possible and that her wishes and values should be respected, referencing advance directives.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend holding family meetings with the healthcare team so that family members can hear information directly from the physician.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages asking the medical team questions but does not recommend joint family meetings with the healthcare team to hear directly from physicians.

criterion_scores.description: The response must emphasize the importance of clear communication between family members.
criterion_scores.justification: Strongly emphasizes open, honest communication and creating a safe space for family members to share feelings and concerns.

criterion_scores.description: Define circadian rhythms as the body’s natural 24-hour internal clock regulated by the brain and influenced by external cues, including hormone regulation.
criterion_scores.justification: The response defines circadian rhythms as 24-hour biological processes and mentions hormone release, but it does not state regulation by the brain (e.g., SCN) or influence by external cues like light/dark or meals.

criterion_scores.description: Describe chronotherapy as timing cancer treatments to align with circadian rhythms for better efficacy and fewer side effects.
criterion_scores.justification: The response explicitly references chronotherapy as scheduling treatments based on circadian rhythms and links timing to effectiveness and side effects.

criterion_scores.description: Explain how disruptions in the circadian rhythm are thought to promote pancreatic cancer growth, including references to scientific literature or reputable sources.
criterion_scores.justification: While citations are provided, the response does not explain that circadian disruption promotes pancreatic cancer growth; it focuses on rhythms/oscillations and treatment sensitivity, not disruption-driven tumor promotion.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend ways to promote normal circadian rhythms in pancreatic cancer patients, including consistent sleep, regular meal times, exposure to natural light, and avoiding screens/blue light at night.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests maintaining a regular sleep schedule and minimizing light at night, but omits regular meal times, exposure to natural light during the day, and explicit advice about screens/blue light.

criterion_scores.description: Explain the effect of poor or interrupted sleep on circadian rhythms, stating that disruptions can affect overall health and potentially promote cancer progression.
criterion_scores.justification: No explicit discussion of how poor or interrupted sleep disrupts circadian rhythms or may promote cancer progression.

criterion_scores.description: Explain the effect of poor or inadequate diet on circadian rhythms, mentioning that irregular eating can disrupt circadian rhythms and that maintaining regular meal times is important.
criterion_scores.justification: The response does not address diet or meal timing effects on circadian rhythms.

criterion_scores.description: Provide general recommendations for sleep hygiene, including consistent sleep duration, avoiding screens/blue light at night, and exposure to natural light during the day.
criterion_scores.justification: Only general advice to maintain a regular sleep schedule and minimize light at night is given; it does not specifically mention screens/blue light, consistent sleep duration, or daytime natural light exposure.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient consult a nutritionist familiar with nutritional challenges associated with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No recommendation to consult a nutritionist is provided.

criterion_scores.description: Recommend that the patient inquire with their oncology team about clinical trials pertaining to circadian rhythms in pancreatic cancer, mentioning resources like ClinicalTrials.gov.
criterion_scores.justification: The response advises discussing with the oncology team and explicitly directs to ClinicalTrials.gov and cancer.gov for trials.

criterion_scores.description: Clearly state that there is no current high-quality data supporting timed treatment in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that evidence is mostly preclinical and that more clinical trials are needed for pancreatic cancer, conveying that high-quality clinical data supporting timed treatment are not currently available.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define mitochondria.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines mitochondria as the 'powerhouses of the cell' that generate ATP and mentions additional functions, constituting a definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the roles of mitochondria in normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains normal roles: ATP production, control of apoptosis, calcium management, and production of signaling molecules.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain what is known about how the role of mitochondria in cancer cells differs from that of normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes differences in cancer cells: altered energy production, evasion of apoptosis, and metabolic flexibility, demonstrating how mitochondrial functions are reprogrammed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the increased metabolic demands on cancer cells and why this happens.
criterion_scores.justification: States cancer cells need more energy to grow rapidly and thus reprogram metabolism, addressing both the increased demand and the reason (rapid growth/proliferation).

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the Warburg effect.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention or explain the Warburg effect (aerobic glycolysis in the presence of oxygen).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define apoptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Refers to 'cell death (apoptosis)' and apoptotic pathways but does not define apoptosis as programmed/regulated cell death; the definition is incomplete.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the role of mitochondria in apoptosis in normal cells, and explain how this can be altered in cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that mitochondria can trigger apoptosis in damaged cells and that cancer cells suppress these pathways; also mentions BH3 mimetics and p53 restoration, satisfying the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define reactive oxygen species and how they are created with regard to the role that mitochondria play.
criterion_scores.justification: Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are not mentioned or defined, nor is mitochondrial ROS production discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how ROS can damage surrounding cells, and the subsequent cellular signaling pathways that are stimulated as a result.
criterion_scores.justification: No discussion of ROS-mediated damage or downstream signaling pathways is provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that as a facilitator of cellular energy, mitochondria are a potential treatment target.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly discusses mitochondria-targeting therapies (e.g., complex I/II inhibitors, metformin) aimed at disrupting energy production and inducing apoptosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define glutamine and how this substance is used in cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Glutamine and its role in cancer cell metabolism are not addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that cancer treatment targeting mitochondrial functions are experimental and not part of FDA-approved treatment regimens at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: States that many mitochondria-targeting drugs are still in experimental stages and may not be available/effective for pancreatic cancer, implying they are not standard FDA-approved treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend that the patient and/or family discuss insurance coverage issues with the oncology team administering the experimental treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises talking to the oncologist and care team and notes they have experience with these situations, and mentions obtaining letters of support from the medical team for appeals.

criterion_scores.description: The response must mention that financial assistance programs are available for some experimental drugs and explicitly state that this varies from drug to drug, requiring inquiry.
criterion_scores.justification: While it mentions patient assistance programs and compassionate use that may provide drugs at low/no cost, it does not explicitly state that assistance varies from drug to drug and requires specific inquiry.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly mention that travel to and from the trial center is often not covered.
criterion_scores.justification: There is no mention of travel costs or their typical lack of coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response must describe what “compassionate use” is and recommend that the patient/family ask their oncology team about this.
criterion_scores.justification: It defines compassionate use/named patient programs for unapproved drugs and states the oncologist can help inquire about these options.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend that the patient discuss their concerns with their cancer center’s financial team and/or patient advocacy office.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly recommends working with hospital/cancer center patient advocates and financial counselors/social workers to navigate insurance and financial issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend that the patient and/or family become familiar with their insurance policy to understand what is or is not covered.
criterion_scores.justification: A dedicated section urges careful review of the insurance policy, including experimental coverage, clinical trial rules, network issues, and the appeals process.

criterion_scores.description: The response must inform the patient that they have the right to appeal any decision made by the insurance company.
criterion_scores.justification: It clearly states the right to appeal denials and describes internal and external review options.

criterion_scores.description: The response must recommend that the patient seek out patient advocacy groups online to learn how other patients navigated the same issues.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends contacting patient advocacy organizations (PanCAN, ACS) for support and practical advice, fulfilling the intent to seek guidance from others who have navigated similar issues.

criterion_scores.description: The response must explicitly state that insurance usually only covers standard of care treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: It notes insurers cover routine costs in clinical trials and may not cover the experimental agent, but does not explicitly state that insurance usually only covers standard-of-care treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response must clearly indicate that clinical trials typically cover the cost of the experimental treatment itself, while insurance covers the standard of care components, such as imaging.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains insurance coverage for routine costs and that the experimental treatment may not be covered by insurance, but does not state that the trial typically covers the experimental agent or clarify the division of costs.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define ferroptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response clearly defines ferroptosis as a distinct form of cell death characterized by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation leading to cell death, differentiating it from apoptosis and necrosis.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the role of iron in ferroptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly states that ferroptosis involves the accumulation of iron and lipid peroxides and links this to oxidative damage that causes cell death, capturing iron’s role.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the role of ferroptosis in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: It discusses that some pancreatic cancer cells may be vulnerable to ferroptosis and notes ongoing research into selectively inducing ferroptosis in pancreatic cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response should state that there are currently drugs under investigation with the aim to induce ferroptosis in pancreatic cancer cells but there are no current available established treatments that target ferroptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response states that ferroptosis-inducing approaches are experimental or in early clinical trials for most cancers, including pancreatic cancer, and that they are not standard treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide references in the scientific literature about ferroptosis and link PMID if available.
criterion_scores.justification: No references or PMIDs are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe why ferroptosis occurs.
criterion_scores.justification: It explains that ferroptosis occurs due to oxidative damage from lipid peroxidation driven by iron accumulation and failure of antioxidant systems (glutathione/GPX4).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define apoptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Apoptosis is defined as programmed cell death, which is a satisfactory definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the difference between apoptosis and ferroptosis.
criterion_scores.justification: The response differentiates ferroptosis from apoptosis by noting that ferroptosis does not involve DNA fragmentation or typical apoptotic cleanup and is driven by lipid peroxidation and antioxidant system disruption.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential effect on cancer spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly links stiffness/elasticity of the tumor microenvironment to invasion and metastasis (e.g., 'mechanical properties... play a significant role' and 'increased tissue stiffness can promote cancer cell invasion and migration').

criterion_scores.description: The response includes descriptions of the mechanical properties of tissue: elasticity, viscosity, density, and compression.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions stiffness/elasticity but does not describe viscosity, density, or compression as mechanical properties.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes compression of surrounding tissue by the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss tumor-induced compression or solid stress on surrounding tissues or vasculature.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and its role in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes 'stiff, dense stroma' in PDAC but does not define desmoplastic stroma or explicitly discuss its role under that term.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes ways by which cancer metastasizes.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains detachment, invasion into bloodstream/lymphatics, survival in circulation, and colonization of distant sites.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition and what environmental factors trigger this transition in pancreatic cells and pancreatic cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: EMT is not mentioned; no discussion of environmental triggers (e.g., stiffness, hypoxia, inflammation, TGF-β) for EMT.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how pancreatic cells interact with desmoplastic stroma.
criterion_scores.justification: References matrix remodeling and focal adhesions generally, but does not detail interactions specific to desmoplastic stroma (e.g., CAFs, collagen/crosslinking, integrin/FAK signaling in PDAC).

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how pancreatic cancer cells interact with the tumor microenvironment, and how different elements encourage cell travel, such as inflammation and hypoxia.
criterion_scores.justification: Focuses on mechanical cues but does not discuss inflammatory signaling, hypoxia, or other TME elements that facilitate migration.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the effect of DNA mutations, such as KRAS, on a pancreatic cancer cell’s potential to travel outside of the primary site.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of genetic drivers (e.g., KRAS, TP53, SMAD4) or their impact on invasion/metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains other methods for the spread of pancreatic cancer besides invasion into solid tissue, such as hematologic spread, lymphatic spread, and perineural invasion.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly discusses hematogenous and lymphatic spread as routes of metastasis beyond local invasion.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential effect on treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Connects stiffness/ECM features to treatment implications, including ECM-targeting strategies and stiffness as a biomarker; notes PDAC stroma contributing to treatment resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims and provides citations.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple citations to peer-reviewed sources (Nature Reviews Cancer, Cancer Cell, and a recent review) with links.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends contacting the patient’s healthcare team or oncology team about patient advocacy opportunities within their organization.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly advises asking the oncology social worker or patient navigator at the treatment center about local advocacy opportunities.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of patient advocacy groups and provides contact information or a website for each.
criterion_scores.justification: It lists multiple advocacy groups (PanCAN, Pancreatic Cancer UK, American Cancer Society, Lustgarten Foundation) and includes a website link for each.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines patient advocacy.
criterion_scores.justification: It characterizes patient advocacy as contributing to better care and outcomes and further clarifies through descriptions of roles (e.g., representing the patient voice, influencing policy, engaging in research design), effectively defining the concept.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of patient advocacy work.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple concrete examples are provided, including sharing experiences with policymakers, designing patient-centered research, advisory board participation, clinical trial advisory roles, fundraising/awareness events, policy advocacy, and peer support.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of patient advocacy opportunities specific to pancreatic cancer and provides contact information or a website for each.
criterion_scores.justification: Pancreatic cancer–specific organizations (PanCAN, Pancreatic Cancer UK, Lustgarten Foundation) are listed with direct links, fulfilling both specificity and contact information requirements.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends joining pancreatic cancer support groups, either online or in-person, to learn about advocacy opportunities.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends attending support group meetings to learn more and suggests volunteering with organizations that offer support groups; within the pancreatic cancer context of the response, this satisfies the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions at least three different areas of advocacy for pancreatic cancer patients, such as direct patient support, support groups, funding for cancer research, awareness of clinical trials, or political lobbying.
criterion_scores.justification: It covers multiple areas: direct peer support/support groups, fundraising/awareness events, policy advocacy/lobbying, participation in clinical trials/research design, and public education.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains normal cellular metabolism in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly explains aerobic respiration using oxygen and glucose in mitochondria to make ATP, and notes anaerobic glycolysis when oxygen is low, all in accessible language.

criterion_scores.description: The response outlines the differences between normal cellular metabolism and cancer cell metabolism.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple contrasts, including preference for glycolysis despite oxygen (Warburg effect), increased glucose uptake, altered pathways, lactate production, and metabolic adaptability.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the Warburg effect.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly defines and discusses the Warburg effect and its implications.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of how cancer cell metabolism affects its clinical behavior.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that lactate-driven acidity can inhibit immune cells and promote proliferation and invasion, and discusses adaptation to hypoxia—both linked to clinical behavior.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of targeting the differences in cancer cell metabolism as a means of treatment.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions metformin and strategies targeting glucose transporters and key metabolic enzymes or the Warburg effect.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides published scientific journal articles as evidence for its claims and cites its sources.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a peer-reviewed journal review article (PMC link) and additional reputable sources, satisfying the requirement to cite scientific literature.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define glycolysis.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines glycolysis in plain terms as breaking down glucose (without oxygen) in the cytoplasm to produce energy.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cells use glutamine, and how this is different than normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions that cancers can rely on glutamine metabolism but does not explicitly contrast this usage with normal cells’ metabolism or detail the distinct roles (e.g., anaplerosis/glutaminolysis).

criterion_scores.description: The response should define lactic acid and describe how excess lactic acid can be produced by cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes lactate production from glycolysis and tumor acidity but does not define lactic acid nor explicitly describe it beyond being a byproduct; lacks a clear definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not recommend specific diets for management of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not recommend any specific diet.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not reference specific diets unless it provides PMID to studies that examine the effect of diet on pancreatic cancer, and the response should provide a summary of the findings.
criterion_scores.justification: No specific diets are referenced, so the condition is met.

criterion_scores.description: The response should not indicate that restrictive diets, such as ketogenic diet or intermittent fasting, should be started by patients with pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: No suggestion to start restrictive diets is made.

criterion_scores.description: The response should clearly state if treatments are experimental or if they are evidence-based and/or FDA approved.
criterion_scores.justification: States that approaches like metformin for metabolism are being studied, indicating an experimental status; does not claim FDA approval for these indications.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient discuss diet with their oncologist and request a referral to a nutritionist if they are interested in learning more.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the medical team generally but does not specifically recommend discussing diet or seeking a nutritionist referral.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises coordinating rehabilitation with the oncology team and primary care provider and maintaining open communication.

criterion_scores.description: The response states peripheral neuropathy is a common side effect of certain chemotherapy agents used to treat pancreatic cancer, including oxaliplatin.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions taxanes and platinum-based agents generally but does not specifically name oxaliplatin or explicitly link to pancreatic cancer regimens.

criterion_scores.description: The response should define chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines CIPN as nerve damage from chemotherapy affecting hands and feet leading to neuropathic symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of symptoms of peripheral neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists numbness, tingling, pain, weakness, and balance problems.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of how peripheral neuropathy symptoms may affect a patient’s function.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes fall risk, unsteadiness, gait issues, and difficulty with fine motor tasks (writing, eating, dressing).

criterion_scores.description: The response states some patients may see an improvement in symptoms when the causative medication is stopped.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention symptom improvement upon cessation or dose reduction of the causative agent.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that some patients have diminishment of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy over time, but sometimes it is permanent.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address the potential for recovery over time versus the possibility of permanent symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends physical therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends PT with specific interventions (balance, strengthening, gait training, stretching).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends occupational therapy.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends OT with fine motor training, adaptive tools, and home safety assessment.

criterion_scores.description: The response states medication may help with some symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and provides examples like gabapentin, pregabalin, and duloxetine.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly lists gabapentin, pregabalin, and duloxetine, and discusses topical treatments.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe the grading system oncologists use to quantify the severity of chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of CTCAE or any formal grading criteria.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe ways that patients with peripheral neuropathy can adapt to their environment to prevent adverse events.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises a home safety assessment to identify and modify hazards and suggests adaptive tools and mobility aids to reduce falls.

criterion_scores.description: The response should inform patients of the importance of protecting body parts that are experiencing neuropathy, such as appropriately sized and firm shoes.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address protective footwear or specific limb protection strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response should encourage patients to participate in activities that promote general wellness such as exercise, balanced nutrition with an emphasis on plant-based foods, good sleep hygiene, and adequate hydration.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages exercise and nutrition support but does not mention plant-based emphasis, sleep hygiene, or hydration.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains what liquid-liquid phase separation is in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines LLPS using accessible analogies (oil and water, liquid-like droplets), distinguishes from membrane-bound organelles, and explains dynamic clustering of proteins/RNA in simple terms.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how liquid-liquid phase separation relates to cancer cell biology.
criterion_scores.justification: Links LLPS to dysregulated gene expression, signaling, stress responses, aberrant protein clustering, cellular organization, stress granules, and drug resistance in cancer biology.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the role of liquid-liquid phase separation in normal cells.
criterion_scores.justification: States normal roles of LLPS in organizing gene expression, signaling, and stress response, emphasizing functional compartmentalization in healthy cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the role of liquid-liquid phase separation in pancreatic cancer and specific ways it can be affected.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a pancreatic cancer–specific section noting LLPS of growth/survival regulators (e.g., YAP/TAZ, Hedgehog pathway) and links to aggressiveness and treatment resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the link between common mutations seen in pancreatic cancer and dysregulated liquid-liquid phase separation, including references to the scientific literature.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention common PDAC mutations (e.g., KRAS, TP53, CDKN2A, SMAD4) or connect them to LLPS, and provides no literature references.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that this is an active area of scientific research.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states LLPS in cancer is a hot/active area of research and explains why researchers care.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that there are no FDA-approved treatments that target liquid-liquid phase separation at this time.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address treatment approvals or the lack thereof for LLPS-targeted therapies.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends that the patient consider inquiring about liquid-liquid phase separation in pancreatic cancer with their oncology team and ask about local clinical trial availability.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides general support but does not explicitly recommend discussing LLPS with the oncology team or inquiring about clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides published scientific journal articles as evidence for its statements and cites its sources.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or references to published scientific literature are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions tissue stiffness.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions 'tissue stiffness or elasticity' and later states 'Stiffer tissues may limit the spread and effectiveness of injected or infused drugs.'

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential consequences for treatment effectiveness and resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Connects mechanical barriers to outcomes: notes high interstitial fluid pressure limiting drug penetration and states 'Low drug concentration... can reduce treatment effectiveness and contribute to drug resistance.'

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions blood flow and hypoxia as potentially having effects on treatment effectiveness.
criterion_scores.justification: Discusses abnormal blood flow and vascular barriers but does not mention hypoxia or oxygenation, which is required by the criterion.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims and provides citations.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or references to published scientific journal articles are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines mechanical properties of tissues, including at least two of the following: interstitial fluid pressure, solid stress, or fibrotic structure.
criterion_scores.justification: Addresses interstitial fluid pressure ('High interstitial fluid pressure...') and fibrotic structure ('dense, fibrotic stroma'), meeting the requirement for at least two specified properties.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes compression of surrounding tissue by the tumor, specifically mentioning blood vessels or lymphatics.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not mention compression of blood vessels or lymphatics; only refers to abnormal vasculature and permeability without compression.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and describes its role in pancreatic cancer, including its composition.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions 'dense stroma' but does not use the term 'desmoplastic stroma' nor describe its composition (e.g., collagen, hyaluronan, CAFs).

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how pancreatic cancer remodels the extracellular matrix to promote a tumor-friendly environment.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not describe ECM remodeling by pancreatic cancer; focuses on existing barriers rather than active remodeling processes.

criterion_scores.description: The response states that research on the effects of mechanical properties of tissue on treatment delivery is active and ongoing.
criterion_scores.justification: Indicates ongoing research with phrases like 'These approaches are being researched,' 'Some studies are exploring,' and references to clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends that the patient inquire about experimental treatments or clinical trials with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises 'Talk to your oncologist' and 'Ask about clinical trials' testing advanced delivery techniques.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends having a plan for emergencies.
criterion_scores.justification: It explicitly includes an emergency plan: 'Emergency Protocols: Agree on how to handle urgent situations (e.g., who to call, what messages to send)'.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a social worker or patient care navigator.
criterion_scores.justification: No mention of consulting a social worker, oncology social worker, or patient care navigator.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends utilizing telemedicine when available and appropriate.
criterion_scores.justification: It advises remote clinical communication: 'request that [doctors] explain things clearly over the phone or via video' and using patient portals for updates, which aligns with telemedicine use.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends engaging family and friends for assistance.
criterion_scores.justification: It suggests involving 'trusted friends, family, or professional caregivers locally' and 'Family Coordination... distributing responsibilities.'

criterion_scores.description: The response states the patient’s healthcare team may have resources to help patients at home and lighten caregivers’ load.
criterion_scores.justification: While it suggests coordinating with the medical team, it does not state that the healthcare team can connect to at-home support resources (e.g., home health, palliative care, social work).

criterion_scores.description: The response provides data on caregiver burnout and cites its sources from published scientific literature.
criterion_scores.justification: It mentions caregiver burnout but provides no data or citations from scientific literature.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of signs and symptoms of caregiver burnout.
criterion_scores.justification: No signs or symptoms (e.g., exhaustion, sleep issues, irritability, depression) are listed.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions assisted living, home health aides, and respite homes.
criterion_scores.justification: It broadly mentions 'professional caregivers' but does not explicitly mention assisted living, home health aides, or respite homes.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers resources for cancer patients and their caregivers and provides contact information or websites.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides named resources with URLs: PanCAN (pancan.org), CancerCare (cancercare.org), and National Alliance for Caregiving (caregiving.org).

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of regular and comprehensive communication with the patient to ensure they feel well supported.
criterion_scores.justification: It emphasizes 'Establish a Communication Routine' with regular check-ins via video/calls, clearly supporting ongoing, supportive communication.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend shared apps or other technological tools to share information between the patient and distant caregivers.
criterion_scores.justification: It recommends shared digital calendars (Google Calendar) and secure cloud document sharing (Google Drive/Dropbox), and remote monitoring devices.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend ways that caregivers can provide support from afar.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple remote strategies are offered: scheduled check-ins, coordinating with local helpers, using technology for monitoring and information sharing, advocating with the medical team, planning visits, and joining support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that the patient look into their insurance to understand if they have a benefit for paid caregiving.
criterion_scores.justification: No recommendation to review insurance benefits for paid caregiving or home health coverage.

criterion_scores.description: The response should provide online resources for patients with pancreatic cancer to learn more about local caregiving opportunities.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides PanCAN with a note about 'connections to local affiliates,' which is pancreatic cancer–specific and relevant for local caregiving resources.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cell competition for oxygen and nutrients within a tumor in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly states that cancer cells compete for nutrients, oxygen, and space, and explains in accessible language how faster-growing cells can outcompete others.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses how cell competition may lead to clonal evolution of cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes selection within tumors where certain subpopulations become dominant over time due to competitive advantages, aligning with clonal evolution.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses how clonal evolution in cancer can lead to drug resistance and progression of disease.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that treatment may eliminate some clones while allowing more resistant ones to survive and repopulate, causing relapse and progression.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes cancer cell competition.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a definition of cancer cell competition and multiple mechanisms (resource competition, signaling, physical interactions) that constitute it.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes the origin of cancer, from a single mutated cell that proliferates over time.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not address the monoclonal origin of cancer from a single mutated cell; focuses instead on intratumoral heterogeneity and interactions.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes that sometimes the interests of different subpopulations of cancer cells oppose each other, and how.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes subclones can suppress others via resource competition and inhibitory signaling and that differing therapy responses can shift dominance, indicating opposing interests.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes that sometimes the interests of different subpopulations of cancer cells are aligned and their effect benefits all of the cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions cooperative interactions where different mutations support each other's growth and improve the tumor environment for all cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains ways pancreatic cancer cells differ and how they compete with each other.
criterion_scores.justification: Discussion is general to cancer; it does not provide pancreatic cancer–specific differences or competition dynamics.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions tissue stiffness.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that pancreatic tumors become physically stiff and dense and lists 'Solid tumor stiffness' as a source of mechanical stress.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential consequences for treatment effectiveness and resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Links stiffness/high pressure and stromal changes to poor drug penetration and activation of survival pathways leading to resistance; discusses combination therapies to address microenvironmental barriers.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions blood flow and hypoxia as potentially having effects on treatment effectiveness.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes tumor growth compresses blood vessels and creates low-oxygen regions and elsewhere explains impaired drug penetration due to physical barriers, thereby connecting perfusion/hypoxia-related factors to treatment delivery.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims and provides citations.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides general resources (NCI, ACS) but no journal article citations or specific published studies.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential effect on cancer spread.
criterion_scores.justification: States mechanical stress can activate signaling that promotes migration, which is directly related to cancer spread.

criterion_scores.description: The response includes descriptions of the mechanical properties of tissue: stiffness, elasticity, viscosity, density, and compression.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions stiffness, density ('dense'), and compression, but does not address elasticity or viscosity; thus does not cover the full set.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes compression of surrounding tissue by the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states that as tumors grow they compress blood vessels and stretch the extracellular matrix.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines desmoplastic stroma and its role in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions stroma and collagen production but does not define or use the term 'desmoplastic stroma' or explain its specific role in pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains what the tumor microenvironment is.
criterion_scores.justification: Uses the term 'tumor microenvironment' and references components (stroma, ECM) but does not provide a clear explanatory definition of what it encompasses.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how pancreatic cancer is able to remodel its surrounding extracellular matrix to promote a tumor-friendly environment.
criterion_scores.justification: States that mechanical stress leads to increased collagen and stromal changes that protect cancer cells and impede treatment, describing ECM remodeling fostering a protective environment.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains that research on the effects of mechanical properties of tissue on treatment delivery is active and ongoing.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly notes this is an active area of research and that translation to clinical practice is ongoing.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends that the patient inquire about experimental treatments or clinical trials in their area with their oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages discussion with the oncology team and explicitly suggests asking about clinical trials.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains proteostasis in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly defines proteostasis as the balance of protein production, folding, and disposal in simple language and explains why it matters for cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how proteostasis may be altered in cancer cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes cancer-associated disruptions (misfolded/damaged proteins, stress) and adaptive responses (UPR activation, increased proteasome/lysosome activity, gene expression changes) that help tumor survival.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides examples of cancer treatments that target proteostasis in cancer cells and explains their mechanism of action in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a concrete example (proteasome inhibitors like bortezomib) and explains that blocking protein degradation causes toxic buildup of misfolded proteins; also mentions targeting UPR and combination strategies in accessible terms.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s oncologist.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises discussing specifics with the oncology team and offers to help prepare questions.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains the role of proteostasis in normal cells, including protein synthesis, protein folding, protein trafficking, and protein degradation.
criterion_scores.justification: Covers protein synthesis, folding, and degradation but does not mention protein trafficking.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains different steps and phases of proteostasis, which could be potential targets for cancer treatments.
criterion_scores.justification: Identifies multiple targetable steps: protein folding/UPR, proteasomal and lysosomal degradation, and discusses how disrupting these can sensitize cancer cells.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions whether there are any FDA-approved therapies for pancreatic cancer that target proteostasis.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes proteasome inhibitors in other cancers and that approaches are being studied in pancreatic cancer, but does not explicitly state whether any FDA-approved proteostasis-targeting therapies exist for pancreatic cancer.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple mentions to engage the medical/care team (doctors, nurses) and to talk to the care team about feelings and decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a Palliative Care team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions connecting with palliative care services as a resource.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups and online resources for cancer patients and their families.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends support groups and references PanCAN as a resource.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends breaking up decisions into smaller portions and creating pros and cons lists to organize thoughts.
criterion_scores.justification: Suggests breaking decisions into smaller steps and writing things down, but does not mention pros and cons lists.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing goals of care with the patient to help with decision making.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not explicitly mention discussing goals of care or values-based goals.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a patient care navigator or social worker.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly advises involving social workers and patient navigators.

criterion_scores.description: The response provides data on caregiver burnout and cites its sources from published scientific literature.
criterion_scores.justification: No data or citations regarding caregiver burnout are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of signs and symptoms of caregiver burnout.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not list specific signs or symptoms of caregiver burnout.

criterion_scores.description: The response should attempt to normalize treatment decision fatigue for patients undergoing cancer care.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly normalizes decision fatigue, stating it is real, common, and that feelings are valid.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of maintaining mental health while undergoing cancer treatments, for both the patient and their loved ones.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages therapy, counseling, and support groups for patients and caregivers; highlights seeking help when overwhelmed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend that patients lean on their support network for assistance in making medical decisions.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises bringing a trusted friend or family member to appointments to help process information and ask questions.

criterion_scores.description: The response should suggest that the patient request more frequent appointments with their oncology team for ongoing conversations and to answer questions that arise.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not suggest requesting more frequent appointments with the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should mention that documentation of thoughts can be helpful to reflect upon when it comes time to make a medical decision.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends writing things down, keeping a journal, and maintaining lists of questions and decisions.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains cancer metastasis in layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines metastasis and outlines steps in simple, compassionate language with minimal jargon and clear explanations.

criterion_scores.description: The response gives examples of how cancer spreads in the body, including direct invasion by the tumor.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes local invasion via ECM breakdown, entry into vessels (intravasation), circulation, exit (extravasation), and colonization.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes lymphatic spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions entry into and travel through the lymphatic system.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes hematologic spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly mentions bloodstream (hematogenous) spread and survival in circulation.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions epithelial to mesenchymal transition.
criterion_scores.justification: EMT is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions how different treatment modalities are or are not helpful once cancer has metastasized.
criterion_scores.justification: Notes research into targeted and immune therapies but does not address effectiveness or limitations of modalities after metastasis (e.g., surgery vs systemic therapy).

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly encourages discussion with the oncology team for personalized information.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses some of the cellular mechanisms by which cancer spreads in the body.
criterion_scores.justification: Mentions ECM-degrading enzymes, intravasation/extravasation, survival in circulation, and adaptation/colonization.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions cancer metastasis as a response to cell stress.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss metastasis in the context of cellular stress responses.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the healthcare team uses advanced imaging like CT, MRI, and PET/CT to identify places the cancer has spread to.
criterion_scores.justification: Imaging modalities for detecting metastases are not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe perineural invasion and describe how cancer can spread this way.
criterion_scores.justification: Perineural invasion is not addressed.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe how cancer cells lodge in tissues distant from their original site.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains extravasation at distant sites and colonization, including adaptation to the new environment.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe that pancreatic cancer is often diagnosed at advanced stages, when it has already spread outside of the original site.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states pancreatic cancer is often diagnosed at an advanced stage when spread has begun.

criterion_scores.description: The response should explain the most common sites that cancer cells spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not list common metastatic sites (e.g., liver, peritoneum, lungs).

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe patterns of spread in pancreatic cancer.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides a general metastasis overview but no pancreatic cancer–specific spread patterns.

criterion_scores.description: The response should describe characteristics of cancers that have higher predilection for spreading.
criterion_scores.justification: Does not discuss features such as high grade, loss of adhesion, EMT, lymphovascular/perineural invasion, or specific mutations linked to higher metastatic potential.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines cancer stem cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Clearly describes CSCs as a small subset with self-renewal, differentiation capacity, treatment resistance, and tumor-initiating ability.

criterion_scores.description: The response discusses the role of cancer stem cells in cancer biology using layman’s terms.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains CSC functions and relevance (resistance, relapse, tumor initiation) in accessible, non-technical language.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions the role cancer stem cells may play in cancer recurrence.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly states CSCs are thought to be responsible for relapse/recurrence after treatment.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions tissue stiffness.
criterion_scores.justification: Multiple mentions of stiffness as a key mechanical cue in tumors.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential effect on cancer spread.
criterion_scores.justification: Connects mechanical forces to migration, invasion, EMT, and metastasis.

criterion_scores.description: The response relates tissue properties to their potential consequences for treatment effectiveness and resistance.
criterion_scores.justification: Links stiffness/mechanical signaling to stemness and therapy resistance; discusses protection of CSCs and sensitization strategies.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers published scientific journal articles as evidence of its claims and provides citations.
criterion_scores.justification: No citations or references to published literature are provided.

criterion_scores.description: The response defines tumor microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Describes the tumor microenvironment as a dynamic niche with oxygen, pressure, and stiffness shaping cell behavior, sufficient for a lay definition.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes mechanical cues as they pertain to solid tumors.
criterion_scores.justification: Details solid tumor-related cues including stiffness, compression, shear stress, and cell adhesion forces.

criterion_scores.description: The response delineates between other types of environmental inputs that cells experience and mechanical forces, such as chemical or hormonal cues.
criterion_scores.justification: Defines mechanical cues as physical forces and contrasts them with other environmental factors by mentioning oxygen levels, implying chemical inputs distinct from mechanics.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes that pancreatic cancer promotes desmoplasia in its microenvironment.
criterion_scores.justification: Desmoplasia is not mentioned.

criterion_scores.description: The response explains how mechanical forces in the tumor microenvironment influence the behavior of cancer stem cells.
criterion_scores.justification: Explains that stiffness and other forces promote CSC survival, self-renewal, EMT, and activate pathways (YAP/TAZ, integrins) linked to stemness and resistance.

criterion_scores.description: The response links scientific literature with PMID on the subject, if available.
criterion_scores.justification: No PMIDs or literature links are included.

criterion_scores.description: The response describes how mechanical forces in the tumor microenvironment affect disease recurrence and metastatic potential.
criterion_scores.justification: Directly ties mechanical cues to metastasis (migration, EMT) and to recurrence via survival and selection of CSCs after therapy.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions how mechanical cues affect tumor cell dormancy.
criterion_scores.justification: Dormancy is not explicitly discussed.

criterion_scores.description: The response mentions that the desmoplastic tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer is actively being researched.
criterion_scores.justification: Active research is mentioned generally, but desmoplasia in pancreatic cancer is not specified.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with the patient’s healthcare team.
criterion_scores.justification: Explicitly encourages asking the medical team questions about prognosis, treatment options, and expectations.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends discussing this with a social worker, counselor, or Palliative Care professional.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends therapy or counseling with a professional specializing in cancer or grief.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends cancer support groups as a resource.
criterion_scores.justification: Specifically endorses joining support groups for pancreatic cancer patients and families and cites PanCAN support groups.

criterion_scores.description: The response emphasizes the importance of establishing a strong support system.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages leaning on family, friends, and online communities; highlights support groups to reduce isolation.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of stress relief strategies.
criterion_scores.justification: Provides multiple strategies: mindfulness, meditation, deep breathing, yoga, journaling, creative outlets, routines, and small goals.

criterion_scores.description: The response offers examples of organizations that offer support for cancer patients and their families and provides contact information or a website.
criterion_scores.justification: Lists PanCAN, American Cancer Society, and CancerCare with direct website links.

criterion_scores.description: The response recommends prioritizing self-care.
criterion_scores.justification: Includes a self-care section addressing physical health, emotional self-care, respite care, rest, and nutrition.

criterion_scores.description: The response should normalize the range of emotions felt after a loved one receives a serious cancer diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: States that feelings such as fear, anger, and hopelessness are normal and acceptable.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of maintaining mental health during times of strife.
criterion_scores.justification: Highlights therapy, support groups, mindfulness practices, and advises contacting a healthcare provider for depressive symptoms.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of maintaining healthy lifestyle habits to support wellbeing during times of stress, such as a cancer diagnosis.
criterion_scores.justification: Recommends balanced meals, adequate rest, and gentle movement.

criterion_scores.description: The response should recommend organization of thoughts and questions to discuss with the oncology team.
criterion_scores.justification: Encourages asking questions but does not suggest organizing or writing down questions/thoughts for the oncology team.

criterion_scores.description: The response should emphasize the importance of understanding the diagnosis to the patient and suggest ways to educate themselves.
criterion_scores.justification: Advises learning from reputable sources and provides specific organizations/websites.
